The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A., currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol at home, is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials. Forty-five years old and married to a peasant, Rose has four children, all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a 50-year-old widowed mother of five children who has struggled to see her children through school, having raised them with the income from her cereals shop.  She has operated the business for ten years but was previously employed.  Jane joined a group of women called Furaha ladies in Faulu Kenya, which has enabled her to save money on weekly basis.  Jane is requesting a loan of Kes. 40,000 to purchase an additional stock of cereals, and she hopes to grow her business into a wholesale enterprise in the future.

loans.use: To buy more cereals for sale

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac S. Ombori is a 20-year-old single man whose business is located at a busy area called Tassia in Kitengela. He has been making and selling mandazi (doughnuts) to the local people for three years and has two employees. Isaac says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he contends with is the rainy season since he does his business in the open air. However, he works very hard to maintain the health of his enterprise.

Isaac will use his loan of Kes 5,000 to buy wheat flour, cooking oil, spices and charcoal to make more doughnuts to expand his business, and he hopes to buy a plot and build his own home in future. He describes himself as very hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, spices, and charcoal for his business

loans.name: Serah

texts.en: Serah, a 55-year-old wife of a driver and mother of one child, runs a grocer shop, a business she started four years ago.  Serah says that her business has really grown since she joined the Furaha Ladies group in Faulu Kenya because she uses her savings with the group to invest in her business.  She has requested a loan of 30,000 Kes and has been guaranteed by the group members.  With the money, Serah plans to expand her grocery.

loans.use: To expand her grocery

loans.name: Magalie

texts.fr:
jeune coiffeuse de 27 ans, celibataire avec 3 enfants dont l'age varie entre 1 a 10 ans,a ouvert un salon depuis 2008,ses recettes varient entre 8000frs a 15000frs par jour.
Avec le pret , elle compte acheter des produits cosmetiques,des meches, des tissages,des produits pour defriser , des demelants, des produits de beaute.
Pour aider a la croissance de son activite, elle s'est specialisee dans les tresses africaines, les plants, les bresiliennes et fait un travail de qualite pour satisfaire les desirs de ses clients.
Pour ses projets d'avenir,elle pense devenir une grande femme d'affaire, ouvrir un grand salon, ou elle pourrait employer des gens et aider a la reinsertion des jeunes filles meres. elle a un bon caractere et fait la fierte de son quartier.
texts.en:
A young hairdresser aged 27, a single mother to three children aged 1 to 10, she opened her salon in 2008. Her takings vary between 8,000 and 15,000 francs a day. With the loan, she intends to purchase cosmetic products, hair extensions, weaves, straightening products, cream rinses, and beauty products. To increase her business, she specializes in African braids, Brazilian extensions, and does a high quality job to satisfy her customer’s wishes. She plans to become a great businesswoman, to open a large salon, where she could employ people and help young single mothers’ reintegration. She is good-natured and is the pride of her neighborhood.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cosmetic products, hair extensions and weaves

loans.name: Zansi Martine

texts.fr: K. Zansi Martine est née le 30 Juin 1961 à Djeffa dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Martine est mariée à HOUESSOU Gabriel, un menuisier. Le couple a six enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. C’est depuis quarante neuf ans que Martine habite le quartier Djeffa. Martine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants, et assure avec son mari les charges de la famille. Martine n’a pas été à l’école. Depuis vingt ans environs, Martine vend divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, bougies, savons, conserves, sachets, piles, sucre, éponge, insecticides, etc.) à son domicile. C’est la première fois que Martine demande un crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle et donc se faire plus de revenus.
texts.en:
K. Zansi Martine was born on June 30, 1961 in Djeffa in the township of Sèmè-Podji. Martine is married to HOUESSOU Gabriel, a carpenter. The couple have six children, some of whom are enrolled in school. Martine has been living in the Djeffa neighborhood for 49 years. She lives with her husband and children and helps her husband support the family. Martine was not able to attend school. For about 20 years, Martine has been selling various items (pasta, candles, soap, tinned goods, plastic bags, batteries, sugar, sponges, insecticides, etc.) out of her home. This is the first time that she is asking for a loan from ALIDé, in the intention of bolstering her business and growing her clientele, and thus her income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various items for resale (pasta, candles, soap, tinned goods, plastic bags, batteries, sugar, sponges, insecticides, etc.)

loans.name: Loy

texts.en:
Loy is married to an accountant and they have six children, all of whom graduated. She takes care of additional family members--two grandchildren.  She owns a kiosk in Ntinda where she sells her pan cakes, chapatti, samosas, and donuts.  She wants to use this loan to buy more cartons of wheat flour and jerrycans of cooking oil. She sells these eatables at the market and door to door. Her customers are market vendors and ordinary people.  

Loy works six days a week.  Her business challenges include the rainy season and transporting cartons of wheat flour and jerrycans of cooking oil from Kampala city to her home.  She aspires to expanding her business to another market. Loy decided to work with MCDT because they were giving out loans to low income people. Loy resides in and owns a four-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of wheat flour and jerrycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a 42 year old lady who is married to a businessman.  She is blessed with five children who are still in school.  She has been in business for eighteen years. She also farms to supplement her family’s income.  She is an active member of a group in Faulu Kenya where she saves her money on a weekly basis.  The members of the group guarantee each other's loans from Faulu Kenya.  Therefore, she has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to add to her stock of fruits.  This will be her second loan from Faulu Kenya.  She hopes to grow her business so as to increase her family’s income.

loans.use: To buy more fruits for sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr: K. Pierrette est née le 29 Juin 1974 et est marié à AGUINDE Gilbert, un tailleur. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à leur charge. Pierrette vit depuis sept ans au quartier Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple subvient ensemble aux besoins de la famille. Pierrette n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Depuis cinq ans, Pierrette vend des friperies à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cette activité lui procure des revenus l’aidant à faire face à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Pierrette s’approvisionne au marché de Missèbo à Cotonou. C’est la première fois que Pierrette sollicite un concours financier de ALIDé, afin de renforcer son capital et d’agrandir son activité.
texts.en:
K. Pierrette was born on June 29, 1974 and is married to AGUINDE Gilbert, a tailor. The couple have five children, all enrolled in school, of whom three still depend on their parents. For seven years, Pierrette has been living in the Djeffa neighborhood, in the township of Sèmè-Podji, with her children and her husband. The couple share the task of supporting their family. Pierrette only attended primary school. For five years, she has been selling used clothing in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. This business brings in income that allows her to support herself and the children. She buys her goods in the Missèbo market in Cotonou. It is the first time that Pierrette is requesting a loan from ALIDé, in order to increase her working capital and expand her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of used clothing

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is a single mother of four children, two of whom go to school. The other two children are working.  She also takes care of additional family members. Formerly Teopista was selling yellow and sweet bananas in Naguru market but relocated to Nakawa market.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches and clusters of yellow and sweet bananas.  She has been in this business for over thirteen years and with MCDT for five years. Teopista receives an average of twenty customers a day. 

She buys these bunches and clusters of bananas from the very market where she works and so doesn’t incur any transport costs.  Besides this banana business she also gets additional income from rental rooms. Teopista works seven days a week. Her business challenges include the rainy season because she works from an open place.  Teopista aspires to going directly to farmers.   She decided to work with MCDT because she needed additional capital.  Her monthly expenses include food, market dues, and school fees. She resides in and owns a four roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.

loans.use: To buy more bunches and clusters of yellow and sweet bananas.

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en:
Vugar is 39 years old and an internally displaced person from Fuzuli city. He currently lives in Fuzuli region (an area still under Azerbaijan's jurisdiction). He is married and has three children. His 17 year old daughter studies in university, his 13 year old daughter studies in a music school, and his 10 year old son studies the game of chess. For the past 3 years, Vugar has been selling the meat and milk produced by his sheep from his home. 

Vugar is seeking a loan of 2000 Azerbaijani manat (AZN) to buy more sheep so that he can increase the amount of meat and milk he produces. There is high demand for his products, especially from his neighbors who enjoy the taste and quality of his products. This is his first loan.

loans.use: to buy more sheep

loans.name: Mèmounatou

texts.fr: Née en 1976 à Djougou au Nord du Bénin, T. Mèmounatou est mariée à GNONLONFOUN Marc et est mère de sept enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Seulement trois des enfants restent encore à leur charge. Mèmounatou s’est installée avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Pk10 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis cinq ans environs. Le couple se partage les dépenses familiales. Mèmounatou a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis cinq ans, Mèmounatou vend des friperies à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Mèmounatou se ravitaille au marché de Missèbo à Cotonou. C’est la première fois que Mèmounatou sollicite l’aide financière de ALIDé, afin de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1976 in Djougou in the North of Benin, Mèmounatou T. is married to Marc Gnonlonfoun and is the mother of seven children, some of whom go to school. Only three of their children are still dependent on them. About five years ago, Mèmounatou, her husband and children settled in the PK10 district in the community of Sèmè-Podji. The couple takes care of the family expenses jointly. Mèmounatou left school at the secondary level. For about five year, she has been selling second-hand clothing in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She purchases her stock at the Missèbo market in Cotounou. This is the first time that Mèmounatou seeks financing from ALIDé, in order to strengthen her business and better respond to customer demand.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing used clothing [for resale]

loans.name: Dieudonne

texts.fr:
COuturier de 44 ans,marie et pere de 3 enfants,age de 10 a 26 ans, ayant arrete ses etudes tres jeune par manque de soutien, il rentre dans un atelier de couture pour un apprentissage durant deux ans ,a la fin de sa formation il  ouvre son propre atelier avec une machine a coudre et une somme de 20000 frs .
Il a une grande clientele,ses recettes sont en moyenne de 12000 a 20000 frs par jour.
Avec le pret qu'il compte recevoir , il pense a renforcer en achetant des pagnes de differents motifs pour faire des ensembles dames, hommes, des chemises, des rouleaux de doublure, de la vegeline; des lots des fils de differents couleurs , des fermetures et des lots de boutons.

Pour accroitre son affaire , il veut faire des tenues pret a porter pour hommes, femmes et enfants,les vendre a des bon prix abordables, il veut faire connaitre ses produits a travers le pays , se faire un nom, pour que partout l'on parle des ses tenues a travers tout le pays.
Pour l'avenir il a le desir d'ouvrir un grand atelier de Coupe-couture -exposition et vente.
texts.en:
This 44-year old tailor is married and the father of three children ages 10 to 26. He quit school when he was very young for lack of support, and started working in a sewing workshop for a 2-year apprenticeship. At the end of his training, he opened his own workshop with a sewing machine and 20,000 francs. He has a lot of customers and his revenues typically reach an average of 12,000 to 20,000 francs per day. With the loan he hopes to receive, he plans to strengthen his activities by purchasing African print cloth in different patterns to make outfits for men and women, shirts, bolts of lining material, some vegeline, lots of thread in different colors, fasteners and buttons. In order to expand his business, he wants to make ready-to-wear clothes for men, women and children and sell them at good, affordable prices. He wants his creations to be known all over the country, make a name for himself, and have people talking about his clothes everywhere in the country. In the future, he would like to open a large workshop dedicated to cutting and sewing, displays and sales.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase African print cloth, fabric and lining by the meter; vegeline, thread, fasteners, and buttons

loans.name: Sisi Catherine

texts.fr: A. Sisi Catherine est née en 1956 à Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Catherine vit depuis une vingtaine d’année au quartier Agbalilamè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Catherine est mariée à MIGAN Pierre et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Catherine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Catherine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis vingt ans, Catherine vend du bois de chauffage à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Catherine vend de la bouillie de maïs accompagnée de pâté (fait à base de farine de blé). Catherine achète ses bois de chauffage à ONAB (Société de commercialisation de bois au Bénin). C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Catherine désire développer davantage son activité et augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, à travers ses ventes. C’est pour y parvenir que Catherine sollicite un autre concours financier de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Sisi Catherine A. was born in 1956 at Sèmè-Podji in Bénin. For twenty years, Catherine has lived in the Agbalilamè neighborhood of the Sèmè-Podji commune. She is married to Pierre MIGAN and is the mother of two school-aged children. Catherine lives together with her husband and children. The couple shares the various familial responsibilities. Catherine did not go to school. For twenty years, she has sold firewood from her home. As a side business, Catherine sells corn porridge accompanied with corn mush (made from flour). Catherine buys her firewood at ONAB (a wood marketing company in Bénin). She is a former client of ALIDé who repays her loans in full. Catherine would like to further expand her business and to increase her revenue through her sales. To achieve this, Catherine is requesting further financial assistance from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of firewood

loans.name: Urunani Ii Group

texts.fr:
Aurea M. est une commerçante âgée de 45ans qui habite la Commune de Rugombo en Province Cibitoke  à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de haricots depuis quatre ans au Marché de Rugombo.Elle était cultivatrice avant de commencer cette activité commerciale. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 3e année primaire. Son mari, Léon Wereshi, est un cultivateur. Elle arrivait au 6e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame, mais maintenant elle commence le crédit solidaire. 

Elle est mère de 4enfants ; 2 garçons et 2 filles âgés de 18ans, 15 ans, 13 ans et de 9ans. Tous ses enfants étudient. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  diversifier les produits vivriers comme le riz et le maïs en plus du haricot qu’elle achète pour revendre aux clients. Elle a l’espoir qu’avec le crédit de Turame, elle  sera à mesure de supporter les frais de scolarité de ses enfants et acheter une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison. 

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  solidaire « Urunani II »
texts.en:
Aurea M. is a 45-year-old merchant who lives in Rugombo Commune in Cibitoke Province, in western Burundi. She has been doing commerce in beans for four years at the Rugombo Market. She was a farmer before starting this business. She reached year 3 of primary school education. Her husband, Léon Wereshi, is a farmer. Aurea was coming to the sixth communal loan cycle with Turame but is now going with solidarity loans. She is a mother of four children: two boys and two girls, aged 18, 15, 13, and 9. The children are all students. She is asking for a Kiva loan to diversify her staple foods, such as rice and corn, in addition to beans, which she purchases for resale to customers. With the Turame loan, she hopes to be able to support her children's schooling costs and to purchase a parcel of land for building her own house. She is a member of the solidarity group "Urunani II".

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Diversifying her staple foods to be sold to customers

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: L. Marie est née en 1949 à Sèkandji dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Marie vit depuis une vingtaine d’année à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Mariée à DANSOU Avocè, Marie est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Marie vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Marie n’est pas allée à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Marie mène comme activité la vente de condiments de sauce (tomate, oignons, piments, conserves, huile de palme) et du charbon de bois en détail à son domicile. Marie s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Marie exerce cette activité depuis vingt deux ans, et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Marie sollicite un troisième prêt pour rehausser le niveau de son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Marie L. was born in 1949 in Sèkandji, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. She has been living for some twenty years in Agblangandan, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. Married to Avocè Dansou, marie is the mother of two children, both of whom go to schol. Marie lives together with her husband and children. The couple takes care of the various family expenses jointly. Marie did not attend school. In order to provider for her own and her children’s needs, she retails sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, hot peppers, canned foods, palm oil) as well as charcoal out of her home. She stocks up in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has been in this business for 22 years, and had previously obtained two credits from ALIDé, both duly repaid. Facing ever increasing customer demand, she is seeking a third loan in order to expand her activities and to better meet her customers' needs.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, hot peppers etc) and charcoal

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is married with six children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members.  Betty owns a wooden store in Makerere Kikoni from where she sells charcoal. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. Betty has been in this business for over ten years. Her customers are from the community around her home. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal.  She buys bags of charcoal from villages of Kiboga and uses public transport to and from buying charcoal.  She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include transportation and the rainy season which makes roads impassable. She aspires to building rental rooms in the available plot of land. Betty resides in and owns a five-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: W. Antoinette est née en 1977 à Grand-Popo au Bénin. Mariée à DOSSOU Florent, Antoinette est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a environs deux ans que Antoinette s’est installée au quartier Lokokoukoumè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Antoinette n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Antoinette vend divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, couscous, savons, sucre, piles, etc.) de façon ambulante. Antoinette achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Antoinette sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu.
texts.en:
Antoinette W. was born in 1977 in Grand-Popo, Benin. Married to Florent DOSSOU, Antoinette is the mother of two children, both going to school. About two years ago Antoinette moved to the district of Lokokoukoumé in the town of Seme-Podji, with her children and husband. The couple shares the different expenses of the household. Antoinette did not go to school. To meet her needs, Antoinette is an itinerant dealer; she sells various products (pasta, couscous, soap, sugar, batteries, etc.). Antoinette gets her supplies in Dantokpa, international market of Benin. This is the second time Antoinette requests a loan from Alidé, in order to strengthen her business and to increase her turnover and income.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing boxes of pasta, soap, sugar and couscous

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en: Otgonbayar D. is 48 years old and lives with his wife in a ger- a traditional housing tent in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His daughter is a student in Darhan, one of the biggest cities in Mongolia, while his wife helps Otgonbayar with his business. To make a living, Otgonbayar sews lightweight leather coats and clothes that are suitable for the spring and fall weather here in Mongolia. He started his business in 2000 as a mobile business. Today, he does all of the designing and selling of his clothes. His working capital recently reached 1,200,000 MNT including the equipment he uses for his business. He would like to expand his product line and broaden his customer base. He would also like to eventually own a workspace which is more comfortable than the one he has currently. Otgonbayar is a hard working person who is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase materials and a sewing machine which can be used to help make high quality leather products.

loans.use: To purchase inventory and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Aubierge

texts.fr: O. Aubierge est née le 29 Septembre 1987 et vit depuis une quinzaine d’année au quartier Abokicodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Aubierge est une célibataire qui n’a pas encore d’enfant. Aubierge vit seule et assure seule ses différentes charges. Aubierge a fréquenté l’école. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Aubierge vend des tissus par le système de distribution. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l’aidant à gagner sa vie. Aubierge achète ses tissus à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Aubierge a bénéficié déjà de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé et a bien effectué les remboursements desdits crédits. Aubierge désire actuellement renforcer son activité et augmenter le stock de ses tissus par l’achat de différents motifs de tissus adaptés aux différents besoins de sa clientèle. C’est pour cette raison que Aubierge sollicite un troisième concours financier auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Aubierge O. was born September 29, 1987 and has been living in the Abokicodji neighborhood of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, for about fifteen years. Aubierge is a single woman who doesn’t yet have any children. She lives alone and supports herself. Aubierge attended school. For the past ten years or so, Aubierge has been selling fabrics through the distribution network. This activity brings in revenues that help her make a living. Aubierge buys her fabrics in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Aubierge has previously received two loans from ALIDé, all duly repaid. She now wishes to strengthen her business and increase her stocks by purchasing different fabric patterns to meet the various needs of her customers. For this reason, Aubierge is seeking a third loan from ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase pieces of fabrics

loans.name: Albertine

texts.fr: Née en 1972, S. Albertine est mariée et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Albertine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Abokicodji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Albertine habite ce quartier depuis douze ans environs. Le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Albertine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis douze ans, Albertine prépare et vend de l’«akassa » (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs) à son domicile. Albertine s’approvisionne en maïs à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Albertine a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Face à la demande un peu plus élevé de sa clientèle, Albertine désire augmenter sa quantité d’approvisionnement et produire suffisamment d’akassa, ce qui lui permettra de couvrir toute la demande de sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenu. C’est pour atteindre cet objectif que Albertine sollicite un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1972, Albertine S. is married and the mother of three children, all in school. Albertine lives with her husband and children in the Abokicodji neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has lived in this neighborhood for about twelve years. The couple shares the different family responsibilities. Albertine did not go to school. For the last twelve years, she has been preparing and selling “akassa” (a local food made of cornstarch) at her home. Albertine buys corn in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has already received two loans through ALIDé, loans which were paid back in full. Facing higher demand from her customers, Albertine would like to increase her supplies and produce enough akassa to meet all the customer demand and earn more income. This is her goal in requesting a third loan.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of corn

loans.name: Baï

texts.fr: Née en 1945, G. Baï vit depuis près de vingt cinq ans au quartier Akpakpa Dodomè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Baï est une veuve et mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous indépendants et qui ne sont plus à sa charge. Baï vit seule et assure seule ses différentes charges. Depuis dix sept ans, Baï achète des poissons frais au port de pêche à Cotonou et les fume pour ensuite les vendre à domicile aux populations de sa localité. Baï a déjà obtenu de prêts à ALIDé et a bien effectué les remboursements. Dans le but d’agrandir un peu plus son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Baï sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1945, Baï G. has lived for about 20 years in the Akpakpa Dodomé neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Baï is a widow and mother of four children, all of whom are now independent and no longer in her care. She lives alone and pays the various expenses herself. For the last 17 years, Baï has bought fresh fish at the fishing port of Cotonou and smoked them for sale at home to the residents of her neighborhood. Baï has already received loans from ALIDé and paid them in full. With the goal of increasing her volume of business and better meeting customer demand, she is requesting another loan through ALIDé.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fresh fish

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.fr:
Mère de 5 enfants, la plus âgée a 33ans et la plus pétite a 19ans, eelle a 6 pétits enfants. Commencée dans ce commerce depuis 1982, avec un capital de 40000f, elle vendait les sucettes glacées, les yahoourts et l'eau glacée en sachets.
 
Elle a niveau universitaire et enseignante de formation, elle se consacre a sa petite boutique q'elle a ouverte voilà 2mois.En dehors de quelques difficultés comme la rareté des produits et l'inflation des prix 
pendant les achats, elle est située dans une zone ou elle est seule a exercer cette activité.
 elle mise sur les produits éssentielles de consommation quotidiennes tels que sardines, pains, beurres, cafés, thé, chocolats, fromages,friandises, sodas sucrés, lots d'enveloppes,cahiers, stylos, crayons, paquets de sucres, boites de lait..... Par jour elle a une recette de 40000f et plus si elle a l'éssentielle des produits. Avec le prêt , elle veut atteindre son but en achétant: 2 cartons de sadines, des sachets des bonbons,2cartons des spaghettis, 1cartons de coneed beefs, 1 cartons de fromages, 1carton des pétites bouteilles d'huiles et de vinaigres et d'autres articles nécéssaires. 
 
Ces enfants sont grands et se débrouillent bien, une fille, la dernière est dans une école socio-sanitaire pour sortir assistante sanitaire. Si son activité prospère, elle veut construire une maison avec boutique pour ses enfants et soutenir sa fille à être une bonne infirmière et continuer avec HOPE pour toujours
texts.en:
Gertrude M. is a mother of five children, the oldest 33 years and the youngest 19 years old; she has six grandchildren. She went into business in 1982, with a sum of 40,000f, selling lollipops, yogurts, and ice water in packets. She has a university education and trained as a teacher, and has devoted herself to the small store she opened two months ago. Besides some difficulties such as the rarity of products and price inflation when purchasing, she is situated in an area where she is the only one in the business. She focuses on essential everyday consumible items like sardines, bread, butter, coffee, tea, chocolate, cheese, snacks, sodas, envelopes, notebooks, pens, pencils, packets of sugar, canned milk…. She has daily receipts of 40,000f and more if she has enough essential products. With the loan, she would like to reach her goal by buying: 2 cartons of sardines, sacks of candy, 2 cartons of spaghetti, 1 carton of corned beef, 1 carton of cheese, 1 carton of small bottles of oils and vinegars, and other necessary items. Her children are older and are doing well. One daughter, the youngest, is in a social-medical school to become a medical assistant. If her business succeeds, she wants to build a house with a store for her children, support her daughter in her nursing pursuits, and continue with HOPE.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cartons of sardines, spaghetti, cheese, sacks of candy, packets of biscuits, butter, sausages, coffee, tea, chocolate.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married with three children, two of her children go to school, while the third is too young. She also takes care of additional family members. Rose owns a stall in Ndeeba market selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Rose buys bags of charcoal from the very place she works, so doesn’t incur any transport costs. She has been in this charcoal business for seven years. Her customers consist of market vendors and nearby families and she sells both on the retail and wholesale markets. As well as her charcoal business, Rose is also a part time teacher at the nearby school. Her business challenges includes seasonality and thieves. She aspires to open another stall in the same market. She decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital. Rose resides in and rents a two-room house and her family has access to electricity, but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Constant

texts.fr:
Jeune homme de 32 ans, marie avec 3 enfants dont l'age varie entre 3 et 10 ans.Apres son Bac,n'ayant pas des moyens pour faire des etudes universitaires, il ouvre un cafetariat ou il sert des petits dejeuners comme omelettes, pain au beurre avec the au lait, cafe au lait, des spaguetti, et des boissons gazeuses. Comme son cafetariat est situe dans un marche , il a des recettes de 15000 a 30000frs par jour.

Avec ce pret il compte renforcer les produits de premiere necessite de son cafetariat comme 50 kg de sucre,  douzaine de beurre pasteurise et margarine ,des cartons de lait, cartons de spaguetti et des palettes des oeufs et tous produits que l'on consomme regulierement dans son cafetariat.

Pour faire avancer son affaire ,il epargne souvent et fasait des tontines parcequ'il a la vision d'ouvrir un grand cafe  dans peu de temps.

Il veut a la longue construire une maison pour sa famille et ses enfants  mettre dans les meilleures ecoles.
texts.en:
This is a young man, aged 32.  He is married and has three children, ranging in age from 3 to 10.  After his high school diploma but unable to afford university education, he opened a cafeteria, where he serves breakfast, such as omlettes, bread with butter and tea with milk, coffee with milk, spaghetti, and carbonated drinks.  Since his cafeteria is located in a market, he earns 15,000 to 30,000 francs per day. With this loan, he intends to boost his supplies necessary for his cafeteria including 50 kg of sugar, a dozen units of pasteurized butter and margarine, boxes of milk, boxes of spaghetti, trays of eggs, and all the products that are consumed regularly in his cafeteria. To advance his business, he often saves money and participates in tontines because his vision is to open a big café in a short time. Later on, he wants to build a house for him family and to put his children into the best schools.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying butter, milk, cocoa, spaghetti, trays of eggs, and sugar

loans.name: Brigitte

texts.fr: E. Brigitte est née le 04 Avril 1975 et est mariée à GANKON Didier, un pêcheur. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés, dont un est à leur charge. Brigitte vit depuis une dizaine d’année au quartier Akpakpa Dodomè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, avec son mari et son enfant. Brigitte vient en aide à son mari et supporte avec lui les charges de la famille. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Brigitte vend divers produits cosmétiques et des glacières dans  son quartier. Brigitte achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Brigitte sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un concours financier, en vue de renforcer son capital et d’agrandir son activité pour mieux  satisfaire sa clientèle. Brigitte a bien remboursé le premier crédit qu’elle a obtenu de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Ms. E. Brigitte was born on April 4, 1975 and is married to Mr. Gankon Didier, a fisherman.  The couple have two children who are both in school.  One of them is in their care.  Brigitte has been living with her husband and child for about ten years in the Akpakpa Dodomè district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She helps out her husband, and together they support the family.  To meet her needs, Brigitte sells various cosmetics and coolers (insulated containers) in her area.  She purchases her goods at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  This is the second time she has requested a loan from ALIDé as financial support with the aim of bolstering her capital and expanding her business.  This is to satisfy her customers.  Brigitte has indeed repaid the first loan she obtained with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cosmetics

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en: Eliud is married to a businesswoman and has one child. For the last four years, he has made a living selling scrap metals and now employees one person. He supplements his income by working as a driver. Before going into these lines of work, he made a living selling clothes. Eliud enjoys his current business because it allows him to recycle waste such as scrap metals and thereby help keep the environment clean.  He sells this metal to companies and individuals. Eliud has applied for a loan for Kes. 30,000 to buy more scrap metals to resell. He long-term goal is to open more outlets for his business.

loans.use: To buy more scrap metal to resell

loans.name: Resty

texts.en: Resty is a single mother with four children, all of whom go to school. She used to make a living selling second-hand clothes but recently opened a pub in the Najjanankumbi Stella Zone, where she sells many types of beer and a locally-made gin. She has applied for this loan to buy more beverages to sell to her customers, and to help pay her business rent. She works six days a week and sells her goods in both retail and wholesale markets. Her main challenges include coping with the rainy season and customers who occasionally fail to pay their bills. Her goals include expanding her business and building her own home that has electricity and running water. She joined MCDT as a way to help achieve these goals, and to help pay monthly expenses that include food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more beverages to sell in her pub

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 35-year-old carpenter who has been in business for two years and now has two employees. He is married, has three children, and his wife is a dairy farmer who helps him support their family and meet their household expenses. John is a member of the Prosper group. whose members guarantee each other's loan.  He has applied for his first loan, for Kes. 50,000, to buy more timber to use in making furniture.

loans.use: To buy timber for making furniture

loans.name: Léontine

texts.fr: Née en 1957 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, NOUTAÏ Léontine vit depuis sa naissance à Houédakomey à Porto-Novo. Léontine est mariée et mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont seulement un est à sa charge. Léontine vit seule avec son enfant et assure seule les différentes charges de la maison. Léontine n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a près de huit ans que Léontine exerce comme activité la vente de glacières, ustensiles de cuisine en plastique, des sous-vêtements et des chaussures à Porto-Novo. Léontine achète ses produits au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo et aussi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Léontine a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but de renforcer son capital et d’augmenter ses stocks de produits afin de rehausser son chiffre d’affaire, Léontine sollicite un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1957 in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin, NOUTAÏ Léontine has lived her whole life in Houédakomey in Porto-Novo. Léontine is married and the mother of four children, all enrolled in school, of whom only one is under her care. She lives alone with her child and is the sole breadwinner for their family. Léontine was only able to attend primary school. She has been selling coolers, plastic kitchen utensils, underwear and shoes in Porto-Novo for almost eight years. She buys her merchandise in the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and also in Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. Léontine has already received three loans from ALIDé which have all been correctly reimbursed. Wishing to add to her working capital and grow her inventory so as to increase her turnover, Léontine is requesting a fourth loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of underwear and plastic basins and pails

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr:
Jacqueline L. B., Maman Jacky par ses amis, est une commercante âgée de 52ans, mariee et mère de 4 enfants dont l'âge varie entre 36ans et 16ans.

Elle a commencé dans la vente du poisson salé depuis 1996 avec un capital de 35000francs. Maintenant, elle est vendeuse au marché de plateau depuis 15ans. Par jour, elle vend 10000 a 25000 francs minimum.

Ce prêt va lui permettre d'élargir son activité en achétant: 2cartons de sole, 2cartons de thon, 2cartons de capitaine, et 1 carton de krovin.

Elle fait toujours un meilleur choix de la qualite de sa marchandise pour attirer ses clients et ses produits de bonne qualite ont des prix acceptables.

A l'avenir, elle veut générer plus de bénéfices afin d'epargner pour  soutenir ses enfants dans leurs etudes universitaires  et devenir femme d'affaire  en important a l'etranger et faire la vente en gros
texts.en:
Jacqueline L. B., known to her friends as Maman Jacky, is a 52-year-old retailer, maried and the mother of 4 children whose ages vary between 16 and 36 years old. She began in 1996 with a working capital amounting to 35,000 francs. She has been selling at the Plateau market for the last 15 years. Each day, she sells 10000 to 25000 francs at minimum. The loan will allow her to add to her stock by buying: two cartons of sole, two cartons of tuna, two cartons of flounder, and one carton of kronvin fish. She has always chosen good-quality merchandise to attract clients, and her good-quality stock is sold at acceptable prices. In the future, she would like to make more profits to save in order to support her children's higher education and becime a business woman who imports from abroad for wholesale.

Translated from French by Kathy Guis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat de cartons de poissons sale; comme sole, capitaine,Krovin; Thon.....

loans.name: Let God Be Group

texts.en:
Tenneh K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Let God Be. She is 42 years old, married, and has three children who range from 10 to 20 years old.

She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support.

For four years, she has been selling oil, rice, onions, and pepper in Saye Town community in Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 20,000-Liberian-dollar portion of this 74,000-Liberian-dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice, gallons of oil, and more pepper. She describes herself as humble and easygoing.

Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Fatumata is inset at the lower right because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, gallons of oil, and more pepper

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Eloïse

texts.fr: A. Eloïse est née en 1955 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Eloïse vit depuis 35 ans au quartier Filla à Porto-Novo. Eloïse est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés, dont un est encore à sa charge. Eloïse est une veuve, qui vit seule avec son enfant à charge et assure seule les charges de la maison. Depuis trente cinq ans, Eloïse mène comme activité la vente de crevettes fumés et de crabes à son domicile. Eloïse achète ses produits au bord du fleuve à Porto-Novo. C’est la première fois que Eloïse sollicite un concours financier de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son capital et d’élever le niveau de son activité. Eloïse ambitionne plus tard acquérir sa propre parcelle.
texts.en:
A. Eloïse was born in 1955 in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin. Eloïse has lived in the Filla neighborhood of Porto-Novo for 35 years. She is the mother of five children, all of whom have been enrolled in school, and one of whom is still in her care. Eloïse is a widow who lives alone with the child she is raising and is the sole breadwinner for the family. For 35 years, she has been earning her living selling smoked shrimp and crabs out of her home. She buys her products along the river in Porto-Novo. This is the first time that Eloïse has requested a loan from ALIDé, intending to bolster her working capital and expand her business. Eloïse's ambition is to be able to buy her own plot of land, later on.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of baskets of shrimp

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr: G. Pierrette est née en 1959 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à DOTOUVE François, un instituteur, Pierrette est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Pierrette a deux autres enfants à sa charge, en plus de ses enfants. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différents besoins de la famille. Il y a environs six ans que la famille s'est installée à Danto, un quartier de Porto-Novo. Pierrette a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire, puis s'est mise depuis une vingtaine d'année dans la vente de céréales (maïs, haricot, riz, etc.), de la farine de manioc et des galettes d'arachide à son domcicile. Pierrette s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et aussi à Ikpinlè, un marché de vente de produits vivriers au Bénin. Pierrette a déjà obtenu une fois de prêt à ALIDé et a bien remboursé ledit prêt. Pierrette désire accroître son activité et ouvrir une boutique pour y vendre ses produits ; raison pour laquelle Pierrette sollicite un second prêt.
texts.en:
Pierrette G. was born in 1959 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Married to François DOTOUVE, a teacher, she is the mother of three children, all of whom have attended school. In addition to her children, Pierrette has two other children in her care. The couple provide for the various needs of the family together. Approximately six years ago, the family moved to Danto, a neighborhood of Porto-Novo. Pierrette left school at the high school level. Then, twenty years ago, she started to sell grains (corn, bean, rice etc.), manioc flour and peanut galettes from her home. Pierrette gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin and also at Ikpinlèm, a sales market for food products in Bénin. Pierrette has already received one loan from ALIDé that has been fully repaid. She is asking for a second loan because she wants to expand her business and open a shop to sell her products.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase grains and manioc flour

loans.name: Samir

texts.en:
Samir A. is a 31-year-old man who sells seasonal fruits and vegetables in Agsu city. He started his business in 2009 and since that time has become very successful. His monthly income is about $375. The fruits and vegetables he sells are very good quality, and local people buy all of them in several hours. 

Samir is married and has one son. He would like to earn enough to open one more shop in another place in his city. Because the products he sells are in very high demand, he believes in his success.

loans.use: purchase more products to sell and increase his income

loans.name: Abil

texts.ru:
Adil rodilsya v 1989 qodu.On ne jenat. On jivet v Absherone regione so svoyey semyoy. Adil uje 2 qoda v etom businesse. Adil molodoy i eto u neqo noviy bizness. On sam soderjit mamu i svoyu sestru kotoroy 16 let. Eta mashina ostalas emu ot otca .

Seychas Adil nujdayetsya v sude 2000 AZN chto bi kupit zapchasti dlya eqo mashini, Chtobi koqda on yexal v Derevni eqo mashina ne portilas po doroge potomu chto koqda mashina portitsya po doroge kliyende bolshe ne yezdat na etoy mashine peresajivayutsya na druquyu a on ne xochet teryat svoix kliyentov. On shitayet chto eta ssuda emu ochen pomojet. 

Tak on smojet uderjivat svoix kliyentov, posle cheqo u eqo budet rasti pribil, i on xochet v budushem vidat zamuj sestru i samomu jenitsya.
texts.en:
Adil was born in 1989. He's unmarried and lives with his family in the Absherone region. He's been in business for two years; he's young and it's a new business for him. He's the sole means of support for his mother and sixteen-year-old sister. The taxi was left by his father. Adil needs 2000 AZN to buy spare parts for his taxi, so that when he takes it out of town it doesn't break down on the road. If if does, his customers won't come back, but will go elsewhere, and he doesn't want to lose his clients. He imagines the loan will help him quite a bit. If Adil can support his clients, business will grow. He hopes that in the future his sister will get married, and he'll marry, too.

Translated from Russian by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy the spare parts to repair his taxi

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr: H. Rachelle est née le 02 Février 1977 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Rachelle est mariée à DOHOU Joseph, un comptable. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Rachelle vit avec sa famille au quartier Djègan Daho à Porto-Novo, depuis près de onze ans. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Rachelle a très peu fréquenté l'école. Il y a quatre ans environs que Rachelle a commencé la vente de divers articles de plomberie à Djègan Daho. C'est à Porto-Novo, mais également à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Rachelle achète ses articles. Rachelle désire renforcer son fonds de roulement et disposer des moyens nécessaires pouvant lui permettre d'agrandir son étalage. C'est donc pour renforcer son activité que Rachelle sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier crédit dont Rachelle avait bénéficié a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Rachelle H. was born on February 2, 1977 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Rachelle is married to Joseph Dohou, an accountant. The couple has four children, all in school. Rachelle has lived with her family in the Djègan Daho neighborhood of Porto-Novo for about eleven years. The couple provides together for the family’s needs. Rachelle had very little schooling. About four years ago she began selling various plumbing items in Djègan Daho. She buys her items in Porto-Novo and in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She would like to increase her circulating capital to allow her to offer a greater selection of goods for sale, so she is requesting a second loan through ALIDé to strengthen her business. The first loan that Rachelle received was paid back in full.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of plumbing items

loans.name: Gulbadam

texts.en: Gulbadam Q. is a 50-year-old woman who sells different clothes and home products in the bazaar of Agsu. She is married and has three children. Gulbadam started her business in 2008 and her income was about 50 Azerbaijani manats (AZN), but her professionalism and good taste brought her a lot of customers as well as good profit. Now her monthly turnover is 200 AZN and she wishes to increase it to 400 AZN. For this purpose, she applied for a loan of 1000 AZN to purchase more products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: His Grace Group

texts.en:
Aloysius C., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "His Grace." He is 56 years old, married, and has six children whose ages range from four to 34 years old. He also cares for four siblings.

Aloysius holds an Associate of Arts degree. For 20 years, he has been selling charcoal on Snapper Hill, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 9,000 LRD portion of this 45,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of charcoal.

He describes himself as a caring father. His goal is to improve his business and continue to educate his children so that they can have a better future. In the photo that accompanies this profile James is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Florentine

texts.fr: NOUTAÏ Florentine est née en 1973 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à SAGBO Claude, Florentine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais un des enfants n'est plus à la charge du couple. Florentine vit depuis sa naissance à Filla à Porto-Novo. Florentine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Depuis une vingtaine d'année, en vue de faire face à ses besoins, Florentine prépare et vend de la pâte de maïs à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Florentine vend de la farine de manioc et de l'arachide grillé. Florentine achète ses produits au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo, et aussi au marché de Ikpinlè. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle, Florentine désire rehausser le niveau de son activité et répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Florentine sollicite un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Florentine Noutaï was born in 1973 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to Claude Sagbo, she has four children, all of whom have been provided with an education. One of the children is no longer in the care of the couple. Florentine has lived her whole life in the Filla neighborhood of Porto-Novo, where she now lives with her husband and children. The couple provides together for the family's needs. To pay her expenses, Florentine has been preparing and selling corn mush from home for the last twenty years. In addition, she sells manioc flour and grilled peanuts. She buys her products in the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and in the Ikpinlè market. Florentine is an old client of ALIDé, having already taken out and repaid three loans. Facing high demand from her customers, she would like to increase her production and meet her customers' needs; this is why she is requesting a fourth loan.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sacks of corn, manioc flour, and peanuts.

loans.name: Petty Traders Group

texts.en:
James K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "Petty Traders." He is 58 years old, married, and has six children whose ages range from 24 to 38 years old. He was only able to attend school through fourth grade due to poverty. He cares for four siblings.

For 40 years, he has been selling door locks, nails, and hinges at Rally Town Market in Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more door locks, nails, and hinges. He describes himself as a business-minded person. His goal is to improve his business and to educate his children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Elijah is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more door locks, nails, and hinges.

loans.name: Durga Devi

texts.en: Mrs. Durga Kumari K. is a farmer who lives the village of Chappagaun. She makes a living growing seasonal green vegetables, which she sells in the local market every morning and evening. She uses her income to pay for her children's education, and is applying for a loan for Rs 15,000 loans to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm. Mrs. Durga Kumari K. lives with her husband and their two sons. Her husband works in a local hospital, and both of her sons are studying in university.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer for her vegetable farm

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is married and has four children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of other family members. Margaret used to make a living selling bananas in Kalerwe's market, but recently began selling mattresses and cushions. She is applying for a loan to buy more mattresses and cushions to sell to her customers, and to help pay expenses such as rent and the transportation of mattresses from factories in a nearby town. She works six days a week and faces challenges that include the seasonal nature of her business, transportation and lack of capital.  Margaret joined MCDT to help address these problems. Her monthly expenses include rent, school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more mattresses  and cushions to sell to her customers

loans.name: Dev Maya

texts.en:
Dev Maya D. lives in Chappagaun village with her husband and three children. Her husband's name is Mr. Ramhari D. and he is a farmer. Most of the people in this region are dependent on agriculture and farming. 

Mrs. D. does handicraft work making different types of traditional sandals out of thick cloth. Most of the people in Nepal use these types of sandals in their kitchens and also in wedding ceremonies. She has four years of experience. Mostly people use these sandals in the winter season. 

She sells her products in Asan Market which is one of the very busy bazaars in Kathmandu. Mrs. D. is requesting a Rs 20,000.00 loan to buy the raw materials needed for her work.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Badal

texts.en: Badal A. is a 38-year-old farmer who is married and has three daughters. He has been breeding sheep for the last 11 years. He fattens lambs both those that his sheep deliver and new lambs that he has purchased. He then sells them for a profitable price in the local livestock bazaar once a month as well as to local cafes. Badal's work needs a lot of physical strength because he spends all day looking after his sheep in the open air. Now he would like to increase the number of sheep that he has by purchasing another 10. For this purpose, he has applied for a loan of 1000 AZN.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sheep

loans.name: Sandy

texts.es:
Sandy S. es una Joven emprendedora muy trabajadora. Ella tiene una pequeña ferretería   vender cemento arena, tubería PVC, pinturas y también un poco de  electrodomésticos, este negocio lo inició desde  el año 2008, como una actividad familiar y aprendió este quehacer porque sus padres le enseñaron , desde el año 2002 por eso se preara y justamente está estudiando administración  de empresas para hacer su trabajo  cada día mejor .En la actualidad  cuenta con 3 empleados, y tiene muy poca competencia en el sector, así que su rotación es rápida por eso realiza sus compras semanales y vende diariamente de lunes a domingo, en el horario de 7:00 AM a las 4:00 PM. Este es el primer crédito que Sandy solicita a  la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo   con el cual  comprarà cemento, Tubos PVC y bloques, además de unos electrodomésticos de rotación  rápida  que ya no tiene en existencia.
 Su sueño tener una casa propia desde muy joven y, pero sobre todo terminar su carrera profesional; Sandy es una joven muy especial que vive en un sector muy transitado cerca de la calle murillo de Barranquilla y también  es vecina del famosa estadio de Futbol de Colombia “El estadio Metropolitano” donde juega el equipo del alma de los Barranquilleros: El Junior
texts.en:
Sandy S. is a young, hardworking woman. She has a small hardware store. She sells cement, sand, PVC tubing, paint and also a few appliances. She started this buiness in 2008 as a family activity and she learned this business because her parents taught her. Since 2002, she has been preparing for and studying business administration to do her job better every day. At present, she has 3 employees and very little competition in the area, so her turnover is fast. That is why she does her purchasing every week and sells every day from Monday through Sunday from 7:00 a.m until 4:00 p.m. This is her first loan that Sandy has asked for from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With it she will buy cement, PVC tubing and blocks, as well as appliances with a high turnover, since she doesn't have any. Her dream since she was very young has been is to have her own home, but more than anything she wants to finish her professional studies. Sandy is a very special young woman who lives in a very busy area near the Murillo street of Barranquilla and she is also a neighbor of the soccer stadium “El Estadio Metropolitano” where her beloved Baranquiila team plays: El Junior.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy cement, PVC tubing and appliances.

loans.name: Ida

texts.fr: H. Ida est née en 1948 et est mariée à ADIDO Gaspard, un marchand. Le couple a dix enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux restent maintenant à leur charge. Ida vit avec son mari au quartier Koutongbé à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Ida assure avec son mari les différentes charges du foyer. Ida n'a pas fréqenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Ida prépare de la nourriture (riz, haricot) qu'elle vend à son domicile. Parallèlement, Ida vend divers autres produits (biscuits, farine de manioc, lait, etc.). Ida s'approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. Ida exerce cette activité depuis une trentaine d'année. Ida a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Actuellement, Ida désire agrandir son étalage et augmenter la quantité de repas préparé, en vue de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et de se faire plus de profits. C'est ce qui l'amène à solliciter un autre crédit.
texts.en:
Ida H. was born in 1948 and is married to Gaspard ADIDO, a merchant. The couple has ten children; all the children have attended school and two are still in their care. Ida lives with her husband in the Koutongbé neighborhood of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Together with her husband, Ida provides for the various needs of the household. Ida did not attend school. To provide for her needs and those of her children, Ida prepares food (rice, beans) that she sells from her home. At the same time, Ida sells various other products (biscuits, manioc flour, milk etc.) Ida gets her supplies at the Ouando market at Porto-Novo. She has engaged in this business for about thirty years. Ida has already obtained one loan from ALIDé and repaid it satisfactorily. Now, Ida wants to expand her display of goods and improve the quality of her prepared meals, with a view to better satisfy her customers and to make a greater profit. This is what led her to request another loan.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, beans, oil and biscuits.

loans.name: Kanchi

texts.en: Mrs. Kanchi D. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati village. She lives with her husband, Mr. Ram hari D., and one son. Her husband is in house construction work and her son works in an electronics shop. Mrs. Kanchi is a farmer, growing different types of vegetables. Due to the lack of technology, most farmers in her area depend on seasonal farming. Mrs. Kanchi sells her vegetables at the local market in the morning and the evening. She is requesting a loan of Rs 30000.00 to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es: Yolanda B. M., vive en el barrio Ciudadela 20 de Julio, sitio    que combina una zona comercial, recreativa con una  residencial llena de muchas viviendas multifamiliares; Ella tiene el negocio de elaborar y vender ropa, el cual inició desde el año 1995, cuando aprendió en un taller familiar de confecciones en el año 1992. Escogió realizar esta actividad  después de ser secretaria de una empresa privada y hoy se siente satisfecha por ello, porque su negocio genera  empleo. Yolanda  trabaja en horario de 8:00 a m a 7:00 P.m. y de lunes a sábado, por eso   aunque hay muchas confecciones, se sostiene compitiendo con respuesta oportuna, precio y calidad en sus productos, asì logra  mantenerse   estable  en el mercado porque tiene  muchos clientes entre almacenes del centro de Barranquilla, amistades, familiares  y referidos  ; la frecuencia de compra de sus materias primas son cada tres días, por eso debe tener efectivo disponible para hacerlo; en la actualidad solicita su primer crédito a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para comprar telas, hilos, adornos para elaborar ropa que tiene encargada. Yolanda sueña con tener una boutique y a nivel personal se siente muy realizada porque sus hijos son profesionales, eso resalta que aunque su estado civil es separado, son muy representativos sus esfuerzos para lograr educarlos y que tengan  buenas condiciones de vida, porque para eso se prepararon.
texts.en:
Yolanda B. M. lives in the 20 de Julio neighborhood [named for July 20th, Colombia's Independence Day]. It is an area that combines a commercial zone and recreation area with a residential zone full of multi-family homes. She runs a business making and selling clothes, which she started in 1995, after learning the trade in a family workshop in 1992. She decided to take up this activity after working as a secretary at a private business, and today she feels very satisfied with her decision because her business generates work. Yolanda works an 8AM to 7PM schedule from Monday to Saturday, and therefore produces many clothes. She stays competitive by being timely and through the prices and quality of her products. This way, she is able to remain stable in the market, because between the stores in central Barranquilla, friends, relatives, and references, she has many clients. She needs to buy materials for her work every three days, so she must have cash on hand to do so. Currently, she is requesting her first loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. She will purchase fabric, thread, and adornments for the clothes she is making. Yolanda dreams of owning a boutique. On a personal level, she feels very successful because her children are professionals, even though she is separated from their father. This is representative of how hard she worked to give them an education and a good quality of life, so that they would be prepared for the future.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fabric, thread, and adornments for the clothing she makes

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith  is married with four children all of whom go to school and also takes care of her old mother. She works in the outskirts of Kampala selling beer, soda and local gin. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer, soda and jerycans of local gin. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from delivery vans. She has been in this business for over eighteen years and with MCDT for seven years. Judith sells to all categories of people but mature ones only. She works seven days a week. Her business challenges includes the rainy season because her work place often floods which makes it difficult for her customers to reach her. She would like to sell wholesale only. Judith joined MCDT because it was giving out loan to five women who are in groups with no security. She lives in a rented two-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer soad and jerycans of local gin to sell

loans.name: Cheri Mai

texts.en: Cheri Maiya M. is 39 year old and lives in Thecho — one of the under-developed villages of Nepal. Most of the people of this region are poor and work in farming. She lives with her husband and two sons. Mrs. M. and her husband, Dil Bhakta M., both make brass religious statues. They have 16 years of experience. The older son is in grade 9 and the younger son is in grade 8. She seeks RS 30000.00 loan to purchase the raw materials for making brass religious statues. In Nepal the cost of education is very high so she is planning to spend her income on her children's education.

loans.use: to buys raw materials for her work

loans.name: Zahid

texts.ru:
Zahid A. rodilsya v 1986 qodu.On ne jenat .Jivet  v Absheron Region. On jivet so svoyey semyoy. V etom biznese on uje 5 let. Nauchilsya on etomu biznesu u svoyeqo dedushki kotoriy bil ochen xoroshim specialistom svoyeqo dela i mnoqiye predpochitali xodit k nemu v etom qorode. Seychas Zahid toje xochet chtobi on toje   shitalsya takim xoroshim no dlya etoqo ne dostatochna znat svoyu rabotu xorosho no eshe nado chto bi pomesheniye qde on rabotayet bilo akuratnim chistim , chtobi ludam bilo priyatno strichsya tam. 

Seychas Zahidu nujno 2000 AZN chtobi remontirovat pomesheniye dlya uluchsheniye eqo biznesa.
texts.en:
Zahid A. was born in 1986. He is single. He lives in the Absheron Region. He lives with his relatives. He has been in this business for five years already. He learned the trade from his grandfather, who was a real master of his trade and had many loyal customers in his town. Now Zahid would like to also be considered such a master. Yet for this it is not enough for him to simply do his work well; his shop also has to be neat and clean so that people would enjoy getting a haircut there. Now Zahid needs 2000 Azerbaijani Manats in order to renovate his shop so as to bolster his business.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Renovations of the facility

loans.name: Man Maiya

texts.en: Mrs. Man Maiya M. has a grocery store in the village of Thecho, Nepal. She opened her store to improve the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of grocery goods such as rice, maize, bitten rice, and noodles. Due to the increasing demand of her customers for the grocery goods, she is requesting Rs 30000.00 loan to invest in her shop. Mrs. Man Maiya M. lives with her husband and two children. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 7 and her daughter is studying in grade 3.

loans.use: to buys grocery goods

loans.name: Euphrasie

texts.fr: A. Euphrasie est née en 1985 et vit depuis sa naissance au quartier Koutongbé à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à ZINSOU Benoît, Euphrasie a un enfant qui n'est pas encore scolarisé. Grâce au revenu issu de son activité, Euphrasie arrive à subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de son enfant. Euphrasie n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis trois ans, Euphrasie mène comme activité la vente de vêtements à la devanture de sa maison. Euphrasie s'approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo et aussi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Euphrasie a déjà obtenu une fois de prêt à ALIDé et a bien remboursé le prêt. Euphrasie souhaite agrandir son étalage et réussir son plan financier. C'est pour cette raison que Euphrasie sollicite un autre prêt, en vue de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
A. Euphrasie was born in 1985 and has been living since birth in the Koutongbé district in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  Married to Zinsou Benoît, she has one child who is not yet in school.  Thanks to the revenues from her business, she manages to support herself and her child.  Euphrasie attended primarily school only.  For three years, she has been running a business selling clothing in front of her house.  She gets her supplies at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and also in Cotonou.  She has already had a loan from Alidé and has repaid it.  She wishes to expand her display of goods and to make her financial plans successful.  For these reasons, Euphrasie is requesting another loan to satisfy her customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing

loans.name: Safina

texts.en:
Safina is married with six children and all her children go to school. She owns a retail shop in Busega selling all types of merchandise. She also takes care of her late sister's children. She has been in this business for ten years. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, and one-litre cans of cooking oil.

Safina sells to all categories of people but by retail only. She rents her business premises at UGX 30,000 per month. She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include thieves and transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala city to her shop in Busega. Safina shops for merchandise once a week. She is aspiring to see her business grow large and start selling by wholesale only. She joined MCDT because they are trustworthy. Safina resides and owns a four-room house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent for her business, school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and one-litre cans of cooking oil.

loans.name: Nirmala

texts.en: Mrs. Nirmala M., 35 years old, lives in Thecho. Thecho is located in the Lalitpur district of Nepal. Thecho is one of the less developed areas of Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs.M. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two sons. Her older son is studying in grade 10 and the younger son is studying in grade 6. Her husband's name is Tari Babu M.. He is a carpenter and opened his furniture-making shop 9 years ago. All the requirements of their family must be met with only the shop’s income. With her loan from Kiva, her husband was able to purchase wood supplies for her small furniture shop. Now Mrs. M. is requesting a second loan of NPR 10,000 to buy timber to be able to fill their orders for furniture. Her husband makes different varieties of furniture such as beds, tables, chairs, and wardrobes.

loans.use: To buys wood for furniture making.

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita M. has a son who is in pre-school. She lives in a single family accommodation. Mrs. M. and her husband Niroj M. make traditional idols. Idol-making work is their traditional job.

They make idols on order. In Nepal the demand for traditional idols is constantly increasing. They do not have enough money to invest in their work to meet the demand. Therefore, they are seeking a loan of NPR 10,000 to buy raw materials such as silver, gold, and wax to use to make idols.

loans.use: To buys raw materials for her business.

loans.name: Mamusu Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the Mamusu group from Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. Fatmata K. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. This 35-year-old is married to a businessman and they have two children. Fatmata has been a businesswoman for many years now. She bakes and sells breads. Fatmata will be using this loan to buy bags of flour, yeast, sugar, etc. In this way, Fatmata will be able to bake a good number of breads for sale. 

The members of this group are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 1,200,000 leones each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour, yeast, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Believe In God Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Believe In God” group. They are small-scale-business women in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. They have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT, a Kiva partner. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and make better profits. 

Kadiatu B. is the leader of this group. She was born in Port Loko, in Northern Sierra Leone. She is 30 years of age, married to a businessman, and they have two children, one of whom is attending primary school.

Kadiatu sells clothes – T-shirts, trousers, underwear, shoes, etc., and has been running this business for six years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying more of the above mentioned items wholesale to add to her current inventory.

loans.use: To buy more T-shirts, trousers, underwear, shoes, etc., to sell

loans.name: Ka-Muyu Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are members of the “Ka-muyu” group. They are small-scale-business people based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profits and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Hawa K. who is age 43 and was born in Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. She is married with six children. Her husband is a businessman and two of her children are attending secondary school.

For twenty-two years now, Hawa has sold cooked rice, rice and palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil). She will use her share of the loan to buy bags of rice, gallons of palm-oil, fish, onions, pepper and plates.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice, gallons of palm-oil, fish, onions, pepper and plates

loans.name: May God Bless Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “May God Bless” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are small-business women who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, in order to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 each. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profits and consequently improve on their living conditions.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Ramatu K. who was born in Makoth village, 46 years ago. She is married and has five children. Her husband is a businessman and one of her children is in secondary school.

Ramatu sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil in the country), groundnuts (peanuts) and rice. She has been a businesswoman for many years. She will use this loan to buy gallons of palm-oil, bags of groundnuts, and bags of rice.

loans.use: To buy gallons of palm-oil, bags of groundnuts, and bags of rice

loans.name: Talapsu Group

texts.en:
