Marie C. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. She was born in Puntu, a village in northern Sierra Leone and she is 35 years of age. She is married to a teacher and they have five children. Three of her children are attending primary school and two are in secondary school.

For ten years now, Marie has been selling fish, baking flour, and firewood. With the help of this loan, members of this group will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Marie will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business. She will buy more fish, baking flour and firewood wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy more fish, baking flour and firewood wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Sun Shine Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Sun Shine” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profits and consequently improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Kadiatu K., age 38. She was born in Makeni, is married to a civil servant at the Ministry of Agriculture, and two of her children are in college.

Kadiatu sells cloth – lace, linens, etc. She has had fifteen years of experience in business. With her share of the loan, she will buy more lace and linens to add to her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more lace and linens to add to her inventory

loans.name: Honest People Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Honest People” group. They are small-scale-business people based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profits and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Mabinty K. who is pictured on the left. She is age thirty and was born in Makeni. She is married with one child. Her husband is a businessman and her child is in primary school.

Mabinty has been in business for fifteen years now. She sells used-clothes for men, women and children. With the help of this loan, she will be able to buy bales of used clothes to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy bales of used-clothes for men, women and children

loans.name: Golden Sisters Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the “Golden Sisters” group. They are small-scale-business women in Makeni who are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to expand their businesses.

Nancy S. (pictured left) is the leader of this group. She is 33 years old and was born in Binkolo village, about seven miles from Makeni. She is married and has one child who is attending secondary school.

For three years now, Nancy has been selling gara lapper (locally-dyed cloth), women’s dresses and slippers/flip-flops. With her share of this loan, she will invest in her business by buying materials for making gara-lappers like caustic soda, powder, ink, etc. She will also buy women’s dresses and slippers wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy materials for making gara lappers like caustic soda, powder, ink, etc., plus women’s dresses and slippers

loans.name: Malaneh Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Malaneh” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profits and improve their living conditions.

Kadiatu B. (who is pictured on the left) is the leader of this group. She is forty years of age. She was born in Makeni, is married to a tailor, and they have two children. One of her children is a grownup and the other is not yet of school-going age.

For two years now, Kadiatu has been selling cooked rice, fish, meat and vegetables. With the help of this loan, she will be able to expand her business. She will use the loan to buy cooking materials like rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), Margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, etc., wholesale.

loans.use: To buy cooking materials like rice, palm-oil, Margi, onions, etc., wholesale

loans.name: Ta Ram Nu Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Ta Ram Nu” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profits and improve their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Kadiatu K., pictured on the left. She is age 35 and was born in a village called Yela. She is married with two children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary and secondary schools. 

For two years now, Kadiatu has been selling cooked rice, fish, meat and vegetables. With the help of this loan, she will be able to expand her business. She will use the loan to buy cooking ingredients like rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), Margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, etc., wholesale.

loans.use: To buy cooking materials like rice, palm-oil, Margi, onions, etc., wholesale

loans.name: We Go Try Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “We Go Try” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Aminata K.. Aminata is age 45; she was born in Makeni, where she is currently residing together with her husband and their seven children. Her husband is a businessman and four of her children are in secondary school.

For many years now, Aminata has been selling fried cakes. With her share of the loan, she will buy flour, frying oil, yeast, a bowl, etc., in order to produce a large quantity of cakes to sell.

loans.use: To buy flour, frying oil, yeast, a bowl, etc., in order to produce a large quantity of cakes to sell

loans.name: Sorry For We Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Sorry For We” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Memunatu M. who is pictured on the left. She is age 32 and was born in Makeni. She is married with two children. Her husband is a businessman and one of her children is attending primary school while other is not of school age.

For many years now, Memunatu has been selling fried food, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), beans, etc. She will use her share of the loan to buy more vegetable oil, fish, meat, flour, palm-oil, beans, etc., in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable oil, fish, meat, flour, palm-oil, beans, etc.

loans.name: Sabineh Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Sabineh” group. They are small-scale-business women based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Haja K. (pictured left). She is age thirty-two and was born in Makeni city where she and her husband and three children are currently residing. Her husband is a photographer and one of her children is in primary school, another is in secondary and the youngest is not of school-going age.

Haja has had many years of experience in business. She sells soaps and Vaseline. With her share of the loan, she will buy more bars of soap and tins of Vaseline to sell.

loans.use: To buy more bars of soap and tins of Vaseline to sell

loans.name: Kamuyu Group

texts.en:
Fatu K. (pictured left) is the leader of this group called “Kamuyu”. She was born in 1965 in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a teacher and the couple has four children – one in primary school and three in secondary school.

With the help of her palm-oil business, Fatu has been able to significantly contribute towards her family’s wellbeing. She has been selling palm-oil (the country’s most favorite cooking oil) for five years now.

Fatu and her group members have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT, a Kiva partner, for the first time. With the help of this loan, each of these borrowers will be able to expand her business, make more sales and make better profit.

Fatu will use her share of the loan to buy gallons of palm-oil to add to her current stock.

loans.use: To buy gallons of palm-oil to add to her current stock

loans.name: Tabor-Su Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Tabor-Su” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty-business people who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions.

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Issa C. who is picture on the left. He was born in Makeni thirty years ago and is married with four children. Two of his children are attending primary school and the others are not of school-going age.

Issa sells suitcases, bags and jeans and has had many years of experience in business. He will use his share of the loan to buy more suitcases, bags and jeans in order to add to his current stock.

loans.use: To buy suitcases, bags and jeans in order to add to his current stock

loans.name: Rodis Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Rodis” group. They are petty-business women in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This will be their first loan from SMT, a Kiva partner in Makeni. With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and make better profits.

Isatu M. (who is pictured left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni. The thirty-seven-year-old is married to a teacher and they have two children. One of her children is in primary school and the other is in secondary school.

Isatu has earned fifteen years of experience in selling market-foodstuffs like salt, palm-oil (the country’s most favorite cooking oil), Margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. With a loan of SLL 500,000, she can expand the size and quality of her business by buying more of the above mentioned items wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more market foodstuffs like salt, palm-oil, Margi, etc.

loans.name: Tam-Tamneh Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Tam-Tamneh” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions.

Aminata K. (pictured left) is the leader of this group. The twenty-eight-year-old is married to a businessman and they have four children.

Aminata has been a businesswoman for two years now, selling firewood and bags of charcoal. With the help of this loan, she will be able to expand her business by buying more firewood and charcoal in large quantity.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal in large quantity

loans.name: Family Affairs Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale-business people in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 800,000, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales, and make more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living.

Ibrahim J. is the leader of this group. He was born in Kono, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. He is 27 years of age and is married with one child. His wife is a businesswoman and his child is still not of school-going age.

Ibrahim is a carpenter and has been in this profession for nine years now. He is seeking this loan in order to buy planks, nails, polish and other carpentry supplies.

loans.use: To buy planks, nails, polish and other carpentry supplies

loans.name: Cheri Mai

texts.en:
Cheri Mai M. is a shopkeeper in Thecho, Village. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are farmers. Mrs. M. lives in a joint family home with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Tulshi M., works in a private office. Her older son is a teacher and her younger son is in grade 10.

Mrs. M. opened her grocery shop 7 years ago. She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, pulse, biscuits, and noodles in her shop. Her children also help her in her work. The demand for grocery goods is increasing in that area so she is requesting her second loan of NPR 10,000 to buy grocery items to meet the demand. She is very grateful for your support.

A major part of her income goes toward her children's education.

loans.use: To buys grocery for her store.

loans.name: Bimala

texts.en:
Mrs. Bimala T. lives in the town of Balkhu, Kathmandu. She lives in single family. She has a three member-family, including herself. Her husband, Mr. Dipesh T., works in private office. She has one son studying in a primary school.

Mrs. T. opened her meat shop two years ago in the town of Balkhu. She sells chicken and buff (buffalo) meat in her shop. She opened the meat shop to improve the living standards of her family. Her husband also helps her in her work. Now she is requesting a loan of NPR 20,000 to buy a freezer to store her meats.

loans.use: To buy a freezer to store meat.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia is married with six children and all her children go school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She owns a charcoal store at her home and sells to all categories of people on both on a retail and wholesale basis.  

She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She buys bags of charcoal from delivery vans that come from the villages, so she doesn’t incur any transport costs. She has been in this business for five years. Her customers are the local people. She works seven days a week. Her business challenge is defaulters. She aspires to go directly to producers. She joined MCDT (a Kiva partner) because she wanted additional capital. 

Olivia resides in and owns a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Gbawulu Group

texts.en:
Ruth D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Gbawulu. She is 33 years old and married. She has two children  aged 11 and 13 who attend school. She also cares for one sibling.

She was unable to attend school due to lack of financial support. For three years, she has been selling blocks in the Thinkers Village Community, outside Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of cement. She describes herself as a serious-minded person. Her dream is to improve her business, build a house and continue to support her family so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy bags of cement to make blocks

loans.name: Mkolemba Group

texts.en:
Meet Selina J. and the Mkolemba Group. Selina, aged 34, is married with six children. She has had a general store for two years now. She works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $68.

This will be Selina’s fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to build her small house and has paid them back successfully. She now wants a loan to buy rice, sugar and flour for her store.

Selina will share this loan with her loan group Mkolemba, which totals 19 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the photo, Selina is first on the right in the back row, wearing a black shirt.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar and flour to sell in her store

loans.name: Kalpani

texts.en:
Mrs. Kalpana K. is 35 years old and lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati with her husband and two children. Her husband's name is Buddha Ratna K. and he is a house painter. Her son is studying in grade 6 and her daughter is studying in grade 1. The economic conditions of her family were not good because her husband's income was not enough to fulfill the family's needs.

So Mrs. K. started goat farming three years ago. At present she has four goats. She sells goat milk in the local market daily in the morning and in the evening. Now, she wants to buy a few more goats to meet the increasing demand for milk. So she is requesting a 20,000.00 Nepal Rupees loan to buy more baby goats for her business.

loans.use: To buys baby goats

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr: Madame Aissatou S. habite à  Ouakam. Elle est sociétaire  de la caisse depuis 7 ans et a déjà bénéficié  de 4 prêts  antérieurs. Elle évolue  depuis 4 ans dans le commerce et la vente de tissus et articles divers. Elle a choisi cette activité  dans le but d’éviter l’oisiveté  et aussi d’acquérir  des revenus permanents. Elle sollicite un crédit  de 500 000 frs pour relancer  son activité mais aussi  accroitre son stock de marchandises. Madame S. est une femme mariée  qui a 4 enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Aissatou S. lives in Ouakam.  She has been an associate of the credit association for seven years and has already had four loans.  She has had a business for four years selling cloth and various items.  She chose this business to avoid idleness and also to acquire a steady income.  She is requesting a loan of 500,000 francs to reinvigorate her business but also to increase her stock of merchandise.  Ms. S. is a married woman who has four children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her working capital

loans.name: Winner Sisters Group

texts.en:
Richael N., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Winner Sisters. She is 38 years old, single and has three children whose ages range from 3 to 10. She also cares for one sibling. Richael was unable to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For three years, she has been selling sugar and rice in the West Point Market, Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more sugar and rice to sell. She describes herself as very hard-working.

Her goal is to improve her business, build a house and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy sugar and rice to sell

loans.name: Jariatu

texts.en:
Jariatu is a serious and very determined businesswoman. Jariatu was able to access initial business capital from her husband and started selling drinks. She has been in this drink business for the past six years. She is married and has three children. She goes to work at 6:30 a.m. and returns back home at 6:30 p.m.

Her challenges are coping with the high cost of transportation and the frequent increases in the wholesale prices of drinks, while trying to make some profit to help her husband support the family. She also intends to use the proceeds from this loan to educate her children.

loans.use: Additional drinks for the pub

loans.name: Teo

texts.en:
Teo is married with three children and all her children go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She owns a retail shop, selling all types of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap and cooking oil.  

She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise, including one bag of sugar, two boxes of soap, three cartons of salt and a jerrycan of cooking oil.   She has been in this business for seven years. She doesn’t have a side business. She works seven days a week. 

Teo buys her merchandise from Kikuubo in Kampala city center and uses public transport to and from shopping for her merchandise. Her business challenges include seasonality and transportation.

Teo aspires to see her business grow larger and to start selling on a wholesale basis only. She joined MCDT to acquire more capital for her business. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food. 

Teo resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.

loans.use: To buy one bag of sugar, two boxes of soap, three cartons of salt and a jerrycan of cooking oil

loans.name: Yunish

texts.en:
Yunish K. is currently in the business of selling bedsheets, dresses, shoes and trousers at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more pairs of shoes and sandals to sell.  

Yunish is 37 years old and married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a salon shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more pairs of shoes and sandals to sell

loans.name: Calvary Women Group

texts.en:
Theresa L., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Calvary Women. She is 33 years old, married and has one child who is nine years old. She also cares for one sibling. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For eight years, she has been selling fish and charcoal in ELWA Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 32,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 111,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more fish and charcoal. She describes herself as a serious business person.

Her plan is to improve her business and continue to support her family so that they can have a better future.

In the photo, Weewee C.'s photo is inset at the lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy fish and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Pure Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Mary describes herself as a hard-working woman. She is 40 years old and she is the leader of the 'Pure' borrower group. Mary is a petty trader who sells fresh rice, crates of eggs, and soft drinks for the past 8 years. She is excited to be taking the loan, which she plans to invest in the purchase of bags of rice, crates of eggs, and cartons of soft drinks. 

Mary dreams of being able to add the sale of vegetable cooking oil, tinned tomatoes, etc. to expand her market and also buy a van to help with distribution of her stock.  She is divorced and the mother of three children from age 10 -17 years. Mary hopes to put aside more savings to support her children to attain university education and build an accommodation for her family.

The other members of her group are petty traders who sell food, palm oil, and groundnuts. As the leader she ensures regular meeting attendance and repayment of loan installments.

loans.use: To purchase food items like rice, tinned tomatoes, soft drinks, vegetable oil, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Delight Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Charcoal is obtained from burning a piece of fresh timber in the absence of oxygen. It is one of the most common sources of energy for cooking in every traditional home. It is also the most affordable. Selling charcoal is a lucrative business for women like Hagar. She purchases bags of charcoal and has been retailing it to customers in her community for the past six years. She also sells groceries, soft drinks, and sachet water. She plans to invest the loan to purchase more bags of charcoal and fill the demand for her groceries, soft drinks, and sachet water. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market.

Hagar is divorced and she is the mother of four children from age 11-21 years. She describes herself as hard-working. She dreams of being able to open a branch of her grocery store and purchase stock in bulk to minimize frequent travel and risks. Hagar believes in education and hopes to support her children to attain better education.

Hagar is also the group leader of 'Delight Trust Bank Group' made up of seven members. The other members of her group sell foodstuffs, smoked fish, rice, etc.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal, groceries, soft drinks and sachet water

loans.name: The Lord’S People Group

texts.en:
Helen F., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called The Lord’s People. She is 38 years old, single and has two children aged four and six who attend school. She was only able to attend school through the ninth grade due to lack of financial support. 

For two years, Helen has been selling rice, beans and flour in ELWA Market outside Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 16,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 56,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of rice, beans and flour to sell. 

She describes herself as a friendly person. Her dream is to improve her business and build a shop.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice, beans and flour to sell

loans.name: Edina

texts.en:
Edina J. is currently in the business of selling beer in a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Edina is 41 years old and is married to a policeman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a salon shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Oumy

texts.fr: Madame Oumy F. est une femme de 58 ans. Elle habite a Ouakam,  elle  est sociétaire  de la caisse depuis 7 ans et évolue  dans le secteur de la couture et du commerce de thioup, wax, huile de palme, miel. Madame F. a l’habitude d’envoyer des habits confectionnes a Tambacounda  en échange  des produits qu’elle commercialise. Elle sollicite un crédit  de 400 000 frs destine a l’achat de tissus qui seront utilises pour la confection. Elle est mariée et mère  de 5 enfants. Ce financement  lui donnera l’opportunité  de développer  son activité.  L’accroissement de ses gains lui permettra  d’assurer la prise en charge des besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Ms. Oumy F. is a 58-year-old woman who lives in Ouakam.  She has been an associate of the credit association for seven years and has been advancing in the clothing sector and in the commerce of thioup (dyed fabrics), wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), palm oil, and honey.  Ms. F. usually sends finished clothing to Tambacounda in exchange for products that she sells.  She is requesting a loan of 400,000 francs for buying cloth that will be made into clothing.  She is married and the mother of five children.  This financing will give her the opportunity to develop her business.  Growth in her profits will enable her to make sure her family has what it needs. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her working capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther S. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell in the restaurant.  Esther is 29 years old and is married to a husband who is an engineer. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase more chairs, tables, and foodstuffs in order to expand her restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell in the restaurant

loans.name: Mercy Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Kwaku is an honest young man who faces reality no matter what. He is married to a woman who is a petty trader with two children, ages one and six. He is now thirty years old. Kwaku lives together with his family in a town called Tarkwa, where he also does his trading. He is able to  support his family through supplying vegetables and condiments like tomatoes, peppers, onions, garden eggs (small eggplants), etc. to retailers.

Supplying vegetables for the past three years, he has made quite many repeat and fresh customers through good customer relations. He plans to invest the loan to purchase 20 bags of garden eggs, 5 bags of peppers, and 10 boxes of tomatoes. He dreams of putting aside more savings to support his children to attain university education, build an accommodation for his family, and buy a vehicle to aid with distribution of his stock.

Kwaku is currently the leader of a trust bank group called 'Mercy', made up of six members. The other members are also engaged in foodstuff-selling, sewing, etc. Members of the group are natives of the same community who grew up together therefore they believe in co-guarantee, respect for one another, and commitment to the group.

loans.use: To purchase of bags of garden eggs, peppers, and tomatoes in bulk

loans.name: Sika Man Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel is a 44-year-old, married, and the father of two children. His children are six and eight years old. He works hard to provide for his family. His wife is a seamstress and their common dream is to be able to support all their children through quality education to enrich their future lives. 

Emmanuel has been operating a pharmaceutical shop for ten years now to help sustain his family. He sells various medicines ranging from antibiotics to pain killers, blood tonic, etc. to people in his community, usually as first aid to treat common ailments such headache, malaria, fever, etc. He plans to invest the loan to purchase assorted pharmaceutical drugs and medicines to meet demand. He also dreams of opening a branch of his shop in another community to serve the people there.

Emmanuel is currently the leader of a trust bank group called “Sika Man” (translated as "Money Man", made up of twelve members. The other members are engaged in trades such as bread-baking, sale of 'kenkey' (a traditional dish made of maize dough), foodstuffs, soap manufacturing, etc. The group believes in respect for one another, commitment, hard work and punctuality.

loans.use: To purchase pharmaceutical drugs and medicines in bulk

loans.name: God Give Group

texts.en:
Rose G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Give. She is 44 years old, married and has six children who range in age from 17 to 27. Her children attend school. She also cares for three siblings.

She was only able to attend school through the twelfth grade due to lack of financial support. 

For three years, Rose has been selling crushed rocks in the ELWA Rock Hill Community outside Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 42,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more rocks to be crushed. 

She describes herself as a strong and determined woman. Her goal is to improve her business and become an international businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy more rocks to be crushed

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan D. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal in a store and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Juan is 43 years old and is married with a husband who is a telecom director. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to hire a car to carry more bags of charcoal to her store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Umgima

texts.en:
Umgima S. is currently in the business of selling various items in a shop such as bags of salt, sugar, boxes of soap, biscuits, etc. and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and salt to sell.  Umgima is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and salt to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: More plastic slippers for resale

loans.name: Salamata Amadou

texts.fr: Madame Salamata  Amadou N. est une femme de 55 ans qui évolue  dans le secteur du commerce et vend des légumes, fruits de mer, huile de palme et divers autres produits. Elle est membre de la caisse de Ouakam depuis 2 ans et  a déjà  rembourse un prêt antérieur. Madame N. a change d’orientation car auparavant elle vendait des tissus et des habits. Du fait de la saturation de ce marché elle a opté pour les produits alimentaires. Actuellement elle voyage vers Diaobe pour se procurer des produits. Ainsi elle sollicite un crédit  de 400 000 frs en vue d’accroitre son capital pour son prochain voyage. Son objectif est de bien se préparer  pour l’hivernage. Madame  Salamata  est mariée et mère  d’un enfant. L’accroissement de ses revenus lui permet d’assurer les petites dépenses.
texts.en:
Ms. Salamata Amadou N. is a 55-year-old woman who is in the commercial sector of selling vegetables, seafood, palm oil, and a variety of other goods.  She has been a member of the Ouakam credit association for two years and has already repaid a previous loan.  Ms. N. has changed directions because she used to sell fabrics and clothing, and given the saturation of this market, she opted for foodstuffs.  Currently she travels to Diaobe to procure goods.  And so, she is requesting a loan of 400,000 francs to grow her capital for her next trip.  Her goal is to be well-prepared for winter time.  Ms. N. is married and the mother of one child.  Revenue growth will enable her to make sure her sundry expenses are covered.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing her working capital

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen D. is currently in the business of selling fish and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fish and some tomatoes to sell.  Hellen is 41 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more fish and some tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Dios Todo Lo Puede 2 Group

texts.en:
Nicolasa is the coordinator of her group, Dios todo lo pueD. 2 (For God Everything is Possible), and her story is representative of her group and generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). Her group is located in San Pedro D. Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and sugar cane industries. The main economic activity is a free trading zone and a cement factory, but both running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure being a divorced mom with her two children.

Nicolasa is excited to be taking out her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her retail business where she sells cosmetics, natural medicine and other personal products. She will use the profits to buy more products and in the future to build her own shop and buy a vehicle for her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To invest in her cosmetics and natural medicine business

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda W. is currently in the business of making local Sudanese bread cooked in oil and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour and cooking oil .  Roda is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more baking flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Tet Ansnm Des Perchers Group

texts.en:
Jaccius, 29, is the coordinator of his group, Tet Ansnm des Perchers, and his story is representative of his group and generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). His group is located in Trou du Nord, an impoverished, agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. He makes his home here in a simple structure with his parents.

Jaccius is excited to be taking his first loan with Esperanza and he hopes that his new business will bring him steady income and make him independent. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business buying products in bulk and selling them in his community. He will buy primarily gasoline and rice. He will use the profits to build a small home in the yard next to his parents so that he can be independent.

loans.use: To buy rice and gasoline in bulk for resale

loans.name: Sayima

texts.en:
Sayima Y. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, sorghum and millet at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and rice to sell.  Sayima is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a storehouse for her cereals.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.use: Stock bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Celina

texts.en:
Celina S. is currently in the business of knitting and selling table and chair sets and is requesting a loan to stock more knitting needles and thread.  Celina is 47 years old and is widowed.   She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine to facilitate her work.  

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: La Nueva Esperanza 4 Group

texts.en:
Ramona is the coordinator of her group, L. Nueva Esperanza 4 (New Hope 4), and her story is representative of her group and generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). Her group is located in San Pedro D. Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and sugar cane industries. The main economic activity is a free trading zone and a cement factory, but both running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and her four children.

Ramona is excited to be taking out her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling underwear and shoes in a Fantasia, which is a variety store that caters to women. She will use the profits to change her house from wood to concrete block to give her family a safer home, and expand her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy underwear and shoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: More gara cloth

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. is currently in the business of selling tea in the evening beside the street and is requesting a loan to stock more sugar, milk and tea leaves to make tea to sell.  Jane is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a builder. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase more chairs and tables.

loans.name: A Changeable God Group

texts.en:
Helena D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called A Changeable God. She is 47 years old, single and has five children who range from 15 to 27 years old. 

She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For 25 years, she has been selling dried fish in West Point Market in Monrovia, Liberia.
 
She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more dried fish. She describes herself as a peaceful person.

Her dream is to improve her business and continue to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish

loans.name: Walekama Group

texts.en:
Korto P., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Walekama. She is 37 years old, married and has one child who is 5 years old. 

She is currently attending college. She cares for three siblings.

For 4 years, she has been selling used clothes in Redlight Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia.
 
She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more used clothes. 

She describes herself as hard-working and sincere.

Her goal is to improve her business and become a successful business woman.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Nowah is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en:
Barbara is a single mother of four children and all her children go school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a stall in Kalerwe market selling bananas. She works on the outskirts of Kampala. She buys bananas from Masaka District in central eastern Uganda and so uses public transport to and from those villages. 

Barbara wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  She has been in this business for ten years. She pays daily market dues of 1000/=. Barbara works six days a week.  Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters. She is aspiring of owning a delivery van.   

Barbara joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital for her business. She owns a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. Her monthly expenses includes food,  school fees, and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Ulloa 1, 2 Group

texts.en:
Tomasina is the coordinator of her group Ulloa 1, 2 (Ulloa). Her story is representative of her group and, in general, of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti). Her group is located in San Pedro de Macoris, a city famous for baseball players and sugar cane industries. The main economic activities are a free trading zone and a cement factory. In many parts of this area, running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and her three children.

Tomasina is excited to be taking her tenth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business to buy rice, flour, other foods, and a freezer. Her business is a colmado, a place where you can find all the ingredients and products to make your daily meals. Normally colmados are in local neighborhoods so that customers have a short distance to walk from their homes. She will use the profits to pay for her children's expenses at the university, to buy a vehicle, and also to finish building her house so that she has a safer home for her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for grocery store

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is  married with  two children and both her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a liquor store selling local gin at  Nakulabye central Zone, Lubaga Division, Kampala District and sells wholesale only. She buys this local gin from Fort Portal, Kyenjojo, and Kasese districts. 

Harriet uses public transport to and from Kasese and goes shopping once a week. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of local gin.  She sells to all categories of people but wholesale and works seven days a week. She joined MCDT to boost her business by acquiring additional capital. She rents and resides in a two-roomed house and the family has access to both electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food, rent, and school fees. Harriet’s business challenges includes transportation and defaulters.

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Carmen Patricia

texts.es: La Señora C. se dedica a la venta de billetes de Lotería con este negocio ella ayuda económicamente a su mamá ya que ella es soltera, nuevamente se acerca a CEPRODEL a solicitar un crédito para comprar zinc, arena, cemento, perlin; y de esta forma construir un cuartito en su casa para su mamá ya que en ella no hay ningún tipo de división y quiere que su mamá tenga privacidad. No posee niños y el único gasto que tiene es el de ella misma.
texts.en:
Mrs. C. sells lottery tickets. The business helps her provide financial support to her mother, who is single. She's seeking another loan from CEPRODEL to buy zinc, sand, cement, and crossbeams so she can build a little room in her house for her mother. Right now the house isn't partitioned at all and she wants her mother to have privacy. She doesn't have any children and her only expense is supporting herself.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc, sand, cement, and crossbeams.

loans.name: Miria

texts.en:
Miria is married with six children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a stall in Bwaise selling chicken. She has been in this business for over ten years and with MCDT for nine years. 

Miria buys chicken from poultry farmers in Kawempe, Bwaise, and Kalerwe.   She sells both layers and broilers.   She wants to use this loan to buy more chicken for sale. She uses public transport to and from shopping and goes for shopping twice a week.  She works on the outskirts of Kampala.  She works six days a week and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale.   Her business challenges includes thieves and transportation. She is aspiring of building a house and also buying another plot of land. She joined MCDT because of its low interest rates.

loans.use: To buy more more chicken for sale

loans.name: Nou Vle Chanje De Grand Bassin 1,2,3, & 4 Group

texts.en:
Roseguerda is the coordinator of her group, NOU VLE CHANJE DE GRAND BASSIN (New Change in Grand Basin), and her story is representative of both her group and Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients in general. Her group is located in Grand Bassin, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and child.

Roseguerda is excited to be seeking her second loan with Esperanza. Notably, she already successfully repaid her previous loan, which enabled her to expand her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business. Specifically, she sells soft drinks to earn a living, so the loan would be used to purchase drinks and ice (to keep the drinks cold). She will use the profits to invest in completing her home. She thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: To further expand her business by purchasing additional soft drinks and ice

loans.name: God’S Knowledge Group

texts.en:
L. V., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God’s Knowledge. He is 36 years old, single, and has seven children, who are between the ages of 2 and 14 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial reasons.

For 7 years, he has been selling drinks (alcoholic beverages) in Thinkers village Community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his portion of this group loan (6,000 Liberian Dollars of the 30,000 Liberian Dollars total) to buy more drinks. He describes himself as a very determined person. His dream is to expand his business and to get involved in the wholesale retail business.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing additional drinks

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en:
Moses S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Unity. He is 32 years old, married, and has two children, who are 13 months old and 8 years old. He was only able to attend school through 11th grade due to financial reasons.

For 6 years, he has been sewing garments and school uniforms in S.D. Cooper Community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his portion of this group loan (6,000 Liberian Dollars of the 30,000 Liberian Dollars total) to buy more cloth. He describes himself as a very committed person. His goal is to expand his business, build a house, and continue to educate his children so that they can have a promising future.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing additional cloth

loans.name: Amor Y Paz 3 Group

texts.en:
Geimy is the coordinator of her group Amor y Paz 3 (Love and Peace), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in Santiago, an area famous for tobacco and beef production, the second biggest city in the Dominican Republic, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and her four children.

Geimy is excited to be taking out her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothes for adults and children and other products like shoes and cosmetics. She will use the profits to buy her children school supplies and to reinvest in her business, in this way she can make it bigger and bring more profit to her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy adult and children's clothes and others products

loans.name: Bertrand

texts.fr:
Jeune homme de 29 ans,celibataire avec un enfant, a ouvert une cabine telephonique, apres sa licence d'economie n'ayant pas trouve des debouches sur le marche du travail, en 2006 il a ouvert un cabine telephonique et vend des cartes de recharges et des Sim , et fait des appels en moyenne de 35000 frs par jour.

Si le credit lui est octroye, il pense acheter des cartes de recharges de Zain, MTN, Warid et des Sim pour satisafaire les besoins de ces clients, et renforcer la connexion avec la compagnie Telecom pour utiliser aussi un abonnement fixe.
Sa strategie c'est d'acheter en gros,et vendre plus, ce dont les gens auront besoin et que l'on trouve tout sur place chez lui pour pallier a la concurrence.


Pour l'avenir il pense ouvrir plusieurs cabines dans les differents quartiers et trouver des gens qui vont travailler pour lui, il epargne aussi pour qu'a l'avenir il puisse s'acquerir un terrain pour construire pour sa famille et ameliorer les conditions de vies de sa famille
texts.en:
A young man, age 29, single with one child, opened a call center. After earning his economics degree, not finding opportunities in the job market, he opened a call center in 2006 and sells rechargable and Sim cards and earns an average of 35,000 frs from calls daily. If this loan is granted to him he plans to buy rechargable, Zain, MTN, Warid and Sim cards to satisfy the needs of his clients, and reinforce the connection with Telecom to use a fixed phone subscription. His strategy is to buy in bulk and sell more of what the people will need on location in order to compensate for the competition. For the future he plans to open several centers in different quarters and find people to work for him. He is also saving so that, in the future, he will be able to acquire a small plot of land to construct on in order to improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Meghan Davignon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cards in bulk including rechargeable, Zain, MTN, Warid and SIM

loans.name: Gregoria Maria

texts.en:
Gregoria Maria has her own tailoring business “Marina Confecciones Cárdenas” which she has run for the past 30 years. As a divorced woman raising three children, having her own business has given her the income and flexibility she needed to be be sole bread-winner and care-giver for her family.

Through FMSD's collaboration, Gregoria Maria has had the honor of participating in numerous design fairs and other special events including Colombia Tex in Medellin, Niña World International competition in Colombia, and in other beauty and talent contests where her designs have adorned prize winning candidates. Gregoria also won FMSD's prize for excellence in 2004, being named Woman Entrepreneur of the Year. 

Through FMSD Gregoria Maria also participated in a mission to Europe where she attended training sessions to learn new design techniques and meet other Colombians involved in the textiles industry. Those connections have paid dividends, leading to some recent contracts with some of the nicest hotels in Barranquilla to make table cloths and upholster chairs as well uniforms for employees at special events.

Through her efforts, Gregoria has greatly improved her family's quality of life. She's a woman who doesn't rest easily.  In addition to her business, she works several nights a week as a guard at a local school (soon she'll be able to retire and collect a pension).  

She wants to continue generating employment opportunities for others through her business, and for that reason she has acquired 12 sewing machines and also subcontracted to others when she receives large contracts. 

Her greatest dream is to start exporting her work to other countries, though the barriers and start up costs are great.  Gregoria Maria would especially like to send her work to Europe.  Her personal philosophy is to not be bothered by problems and complications, because she knows she can overcome anything.  From time to time she's had to confront clients as well as sub-contractors who didn't deliver, but she's always risen above.

Gregoria Maria is a positive woman who is working hard to grow her business, a business that has enabled her to put two children through college,  buy her own home, get a car, and employ several women.  She's asked for this loan from Kiva through FMSD to help pay for her youngest son's university studies. 


[EN ESPANOL]

Gregoria Cárdenas, propietaria de “Marina Confecciones Cárdenas” tiene este negocio, desde que decidió mejorar su calidad de vida hace ya 30 años, cuando sola con la responsabilidad de sus 3 hijos, emprendió la hoy microempresa dedicada a fabricar prendas de vestir en todas las  líneas  conocidas, porque conoce muy bien su arte y gradualmente lo ha perfeccionada con el tiempo y de la mano de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, quien la ha impulsado aprovechando su gran potencial de crecimiento como persona, como mujer y como empresaria. Gracias a este apoyo ha participado en ferias importantes de la confección, como en Colombia Tex en Medellín, en el certamen niña Word de Colombia, y en jornadas de belleza y talento donde ha ganado premios. Gregoria cuenta, como al mismo tiempo que la Fundación ganó el premio a la excelencia, ella en ese mismo año también le otorgaron el premio a la mujer empresaria del año 2004 y también como, a través de esta organización participo  en la Misión a Europa, donde mediante jornadas formativas aprendió nuevas técnicas y la actualización de diseños y consiguió muchas amistades del mismo sector de la confección en Colombia, lo que  la ha  llevado a obtener contratos en los hoteles mas importantes de Barranquilla, a quienes hoy en día les confecciona los manteles, viste también las sillas de las mesas y eventos importantes y fabrica la ropa de sus empleados. 
Gregoria Marina con grandes esfuerzos de trabajo ha sacado a su familia adelante,  porque es una mujer que no se queda quieta, pues así como tiene su negocio de confecciones, también trabaja en la noche en un colegio como secretaria,  donde está próxima a recibir su pensión por jubilación.  Su deseo siempre es generar empleo por eso además de poner a funcionar sus 12 maquinas de confección, también trabaja mediante talleres satélites cuando consigue los buenos contratos de los que siempre esta en su búsqueda. Ahora sueña con exportar, pero le parecen muy dispendioso los requisitos y costos para hacerlo le gustaría que fuera a Europa  porque ganaría en euros,  En su filosofía no  plantea  el termino problemas, porque siempre logra lo que quiere, pero cree que lo mas difícil es  cuando los clientes no pagan a tiempo y ella necesita responder a sus operarias y a la producción. De todas maneras es una mujer feliz porque sus hijos son profesionales y el último está en la universidad, siendo justamente la solicitud  de crédito que hace a la Fundación para pagarle su semestre. Gregoria Marina se manifiesta como una mujer prospera y exitosa, que con su esfuerzo   tiene una casa que ha adecuado como ha querido, un carro nuevo para transportarse, un importante taller de confección  que produce y genera empleo  y una maravillosa familia que también avanza con pasos firmes.

loans.use: Pay for son's university studies.

loans.name: Maria Ines

texts.es:
María Inés tiene 57 años D. edad, resiD. en el Municipio D. San Simón, Departamento D.  Morazán, vive con su esposo y tres hijos, y su actividad es agropecuaria.
 Se dedica a la siembra D. maíz y crianza D. animales D. corral, siempre se ha dedicado a esta actividad ya que vive en una zona rural que se presta para esta actividad, María necesita un préstamo para compra D. fertilizante y abono para obtener una buena cosecha D. maíz.
Esto ayudaría a garantizar que la familia D. María tenga un cosecha que les permita vender una parte y utilizar otra para el gasto del hogar, con la confianza que las lluvias sean favorables para la cosecha.
Su Objetivos son ayudar a su familia, generar ingreso para las necesidades básicas, y darle a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en:
María Inés, age 57, lives in the San Simón municipality in the Morazán department. She lives with her husband and their three children. Her activity is farming. She plants corn and raises farm animals. She has always done this work because she lives in a rural area, which lends itself to this activity. María needs a loan to buy chemical and natural fertilizers in order to have a good corn harvest. This will help to guarantee that María’s family has a harvest, which will allow them to sell part of it and use the other part for household expenses. This is dependent upon the rains being favorable for the harvest. Her objectives are to help her family, to generate income for their basic needs, and to give her family a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy natural and chemical fertilizers

location.town: Canton San Francisco, San Simon, Morazan.

loans.name: Hernando Rafael

texts.es:
Muy cerca al mar en un municipio llamado Puerto Colombia, al norte del departamento de Atlántico,  Hernando Álvarez tiene su  maquinaria de coser y herramientas, con las que  fabrica y repara calzado ; allí  su nombre  es muy conocido porque maneja muy bien la línea femenina de sandalias, que por el clima son muy utilizadas en este departamento. Hernando inició su negocio cuando estaba desempleado hace 5 años y un amigo le ofreció asociarse con él para fabricar sandalias,  aunque inició con poco capital y rudimentarias herramientas, ha logrado perfeccionar su arte pues es un autodidacta, que de cualquier  revista de calzado que pasa por su mano,  extrae los más hermosos modelos que luego plasma y convierte en elegantes, sandalias en los estilos formales e informales que adornas el pie  de sus clientes.
En la actualidad, Hernando solicita su primer crédito  a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, para invertir en la compra de materias primas  e insumos para fabricar sandalias femeninas, como suelas, gomas, herrajes, sintéticos y accesorios, con los cuales desarrollará  diseños que están de moda. Hernando y su conyugue, sueñan con ofrecerle una educación  de calidad a su hijo de   5 años de edad, por eso a   corto plazo su meta es  comprar una maquina industrial nueva, que reemplace a la vieja máquina de coser que actualmente usa, porque  en su proceso productivo  su mayor desafío es la demora en la entrega de los pedidos, por carecer de maquinarias más modernas que ayuden a  que sus procesos sean eficientes .
texts.en:
Very near the sea in a town called Puerto Columbia, in the Northern State of Atlantico, Hernando Álvarez has his sewing machine and tools with which he makes and repairs shoes. His name is very well known there because he creates a very fine line of women's sandals, which for the climate are very useful in his state. Hernando began his business when he was unemployed five years ago, and a friend invited him to join the sandal-making business. Although he started out with little capital and a few tools, he has perfected his art though self-instruction and paying attention to whatever shoe magazine passed through his hands He takes the most beautiful styles and makes a basic form converting them into elegant sandals in formal and informal styles that adorn his clients' feet. Currently, Hernando is asking for his first loan from the Maria Santo Domingo Foundation, to invest in the purchase of raw materials and basic elements to make women's sandals, such as soles, glue, tools, synthetics, and accessories with which he will develop stylish designs. Hernando and his life partner dream of providing a quality education to their 5-year-old child. For this reason, his short-term goal is to buy a new industrial machine to replace the old sewing machine that he currently uses. In his production process, his biggest challenge is the time delay between orders and delivery, due to a lack of modern machinery, which will help make the process more efficient.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of raw materials and items for making women's sandals, soles, rubber, tooled, synthetic and accessories

loans.name: Jose Pedro

texts.es:
José tiene 48 años de edad, reside en el cantón Corralito, Corinto Morazán, está acompañado, y se dedica a la agricultura. 
 Tiene  veinticinco  años de realizar el trabajo de  cultivo de granos y fue su padre quien le inculco el trabajar la tierra,  siembra Maíz, frijol y maicillo, trabaja en horario de 6:00 am a 2:00 pm, le gusta mucho su trabajo, actualmente se ha visto en la necesidad de adquirir un préstamo  para invertirlo en compra de abono y fertilizante para el cultivo de maíz.
Con la compra de abono José espera tener una producción favorable de la cual planea vender una parte y otra para consumo de su familia; Sus aspiraciones obtener un exetente Cultivo, comprar a futuro animales:  Vacas y cerdos  dedicarce al cuidado y venta para mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Jose is 48 years old, and resides in the Corralito canton, living in the Corinto Morazán state. He work in farming. He has been a farmer, growing grain for 25 years. It was his father who got him into farming, sewing corn, beans, and native corn, he works from 6:00 in the morning until 2:00 in the afternoon. He likes his work a lot and currently he has seen the need to acquire a loan to invest in the purchase of fertilizer and nutrients for his corn crop. With the purchase of fertilizer, Jose hopes to have a more bountiful harvest, from which he plans to sell one part and his family will consume the other part. He aspires to have a flourishing harvest to buy animals in the future such as cows and pigs and to devote himself to raising and selling cattle and improve the quality of his family's life.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy nutrients and fertilizer to grow corn

loans.name: Dora Elizabeth

texts.es:
Dora tiene 42 años de edad, reside en San Miguel, es casada tiene dos hijos vannesa y David de 14 y 16 respectiva, están estudiando, se dedica a elaboración y venta pupusas (tortilla de maíz con queso y chicharon).
Dora necesita el préstamo para la compra de materiales para la elaboración de pupusas (harina de maíz, aceite, queso, carne de cerdo, gas, cafe, cholate), con la compra de estos productos considera que contribuirá a continuar con su negocio, para que generar ingresos y solventar las necesidades de su familia. 
Su objetivo es tener más clientes y ofrecer nuevos productos, mejorar los ingresos de su negocio para mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Dora is 42 years old, she resides in San Miguel and is married and has two children, Vannesa and David ages 14 and 16 respectively. They are studying. She is in the business of preparing and selling pupusas (corn tortillas with cheese and pork rinds). Dora needs the loan to buy cooking ingredients for making pupusas (corn flour, oil, cheese, pork, cooking gas, coffee and cholate). With the purchase of these products, she feels it will contribute to her continuing her business, generate earnings and cover her family's needs. Her objective is to have more clients and to offer new products, improving her earnings and the quality of her family's life.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purhase of corn flour, oil, cheese, pork, cooking gas, coffee and cholate.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.es:
En el barrio el Carmen del municipio de Puerto Colombia muy cerca al mar, vive Bernardo Rodríguez, un hombre muy alegre que vende pescado de ma, actividad  que desempeñó desde muy joven, cuando se dedicaba a la pesca marítima artesanal en Puerto Colombia y desde hace ya más de 30 años, la convirtió  en su negocio, que consiste en la compra y venta de este producto del mar. Y es que Bernardo ofrece a sus clientes un buen precio, debido a  que sus compras por volumen le dan esta posibilidad. Como Puerto Colombia se encuentra a 30 minutos, vía terrestre de la ciudad de Barranquilla y muy cerca a otros municipios del Departamento del Atlántico,  es usual que los fines de semana   muchas familias que hacen turismo a este puerto, muy seguramente se desayunen o almuercen con  pescados marinos como pargos, cojinúa, el carito, lebranche, robalo, sábalo y sierra,  que vende muy frescos y recién pescados,   Bernardo a los restaurantes y hoteles o estaderos que allí se encuentra. En la actualidad él está solicitando su primer crédito a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y quiere comprar pescado de mar en mayor cantidad, porque últimamente se ha incrementado el número de clientes a los que no ha podido responder.
Su sueño es abrir un local comercial en el centro de Puerto Colombia,  bien equipado con sus cuartos fríos,   donde cualquier consumidor en todo el departamento y en este municipio, encuentre los más deliciosos y frescos pescados .Su desafío se presenta cuando existen cambios climáticos y contaminación marítima que disminuyen  la pesca artesanal , afectando la economía de estos puertos, donde  la mayor parte de sus habitantes,  viven de  la pesca y  sus derivados, es decir tienen negocios de alimentos y el pescado es su producto estrella.
texts.en:
Bernardo Rodríguez lives in Carmen, in the district of Puerto Colombia, close to the sea. He is a very cheerful man, who earns his living selling fish. He has held this occupation for over 30 years, since he was a very young man working in the local maritime fishing industry in Puerto Colombia. He now runs his own business, which consists of buying and selling produce from the sea. Bernardo offers his customers very good prices, thanks to the bulk purchases he makes. Since Puerto Colombia is only 30 minutes away by land from the town of Barranquilla, very near to other districts in the Department of Atlántico, it is a popular tourist destination for families on the weekends. It is very likely that many eat the freshly-caught fish - such as pargos (snapper), cojinúa (blue runner), 'el carito', 'lebranche', robalo (snook), and sierra (kingfish) - that Bernardo sells to the restaurants and hotels or inns located there. This will be Bernardo's first loan from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, which he wants to spend on buying greater quantities of fish to satisfy his growing number of customers. His dream is to open a shop in the centre of Puerto Colombia, which would be well-equipped with cold rooms where customers from all over the department and local district could find the most delicious, fresh fish. Among the challenges he faces are climate change and maritime pollution. This affects local fishing and the economy of these ports, since most inhabitants depend on fishing and associated business.

Translated from Spanish by Cameron Graham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of fish, such as pargos (snapper), cojinúa (blue runner), 'el carito', 'lebranche', robalo (snook), and sierra (kingfish)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of raw materials such as oil, salt and corn in larger quantities.

loans.name: Gioconda

texts.es:
Doña Gioconda tiene la edad de 44 años, vive en el barrio Concepción de Maria, casada, madre de cinco hijos.
Su negocio es la venta de ropa, y venta de tortillas, negocio que inicio hace varios años con el objetivo de generar ingresos para su familia. Lo que vino a mejorar en la alimentación y pagos básicos. Que es lo mas caro y necesario.
Con este financiamiento lograra invertir en compra de ropa, compra de varios quintales de maíz, cal, carbón entre otros para aumentar su producción de venta de tortillas. Y lograr captar cada día clientes.
texts.en:
Gioconda is 44 years old and lives in Concepción de María barrio. She is married and the mother of 5 children. Her business is to sell clothes and tortillas. She started the business some years ago with the object of generating income for her family. The business has improved the family's nutrition and helped with basic expenses, the most costly and necessary of all. With this loan, she will invest in clothes to sell and various hundred-weights of corn, lime and charcoal, among other things, to augment the production and sale of tortillas. This should help her to capture more customers each day.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING HUNDRED-WEIGHTS OF CORN, CHARCOAL, LIME, PLUS CLOTHES TO CONTINUE IMPROVING SALES INCOME

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Dénise

texts.fr:
Mariée , mère de 6 enfants et âgée de 44ans, cette dame exerce la vente du poisson salé comme le faisait sa maman.elle a commencée avec la vente des  divers condiments et assaisonements, oignons, ails ,boites de tomates, poivres,thym, cubes de bouillons.elle a avait un capital de 25000f, son niveau d'étude est moyen.
le prêt actuel  lui permettra de d'agrandir son activité en achétant: 3cartons de thon, 3cartons de capitaine, 3cartons morue.Elle est dans un quartier ou le poisson salé est beaucoup mangé, pour cela , elle compte réaliser beacoup de bénéfice.
Si elle ne tombe pas sur du mauvais poisson salé, elle vend  entre 45000f à 50000f par jour.Son but avec cette institution de micro-finance est d'aller plus loin dans les affaires et aider ses voisines dans la gestion de leurs activités.
Ses rêves  sont ,être grossiste, voyager pour connaitre  d'autres creneaux d'achats de poisson salé,construire une boutique  de vente de poisson sale en gros et  soutenir ses enfants a faire des longues etudes . 
Dans son milieu  , on pense qu'elle est calme, on l' appelle mama tranquile.
texts.en:
Married, the mother of six children and 44 years of age, this woman is in the business of selling salted fish, just as her mother used to do. She started selling different condiments and seasonings, such as onions, garlic, canned tomatoes, peppers, thyme, and bouillon cubes. She had a starting capital of 25000 Central African Francs; she has received secondary education. The current loan will allow her to expand her activities by purchasing three boxes of tuna, three boxes of bream and three boxes of cod. She lives in a neighborhood where salted fish is eaten a lot, and because of this she counts on earning a good income. Unless some of the fish she had purchased turns to be bad, her sales range from 45000 to 50000 Central African francs per day. Her goal in partnering with this microfinance institution is to take her business to the next levels and to help her neighbors with their business. Her dream is to become a wholesaler, travel to discover other good markets for purchasing salted fish, build a shop for selling salted fish wholesale and support upper-level studies for her children. In her neighborhood, she has a reputation for being a calm person; she is nicknamed “the tranquil mama.”

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing boxes of salted fish (tuna, bream, cod)

loans.name: Marie Danièle

texts.fr: Marie Danièle M. est une femme de 37 ans; elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de femmes Catholiques de Tambacounda depuis l'inauguration dudit Banc Villageois le 27 juillet 2008, elle y a reçu 04 prêts qu'elle a toujours bien remboursé. Elle est détentrice d'une boutique et avec son nouveau prêt elle va s'équiper en achetant un réfrigérateur afin de vendre des rafraichissements elle va  même temps acheter et revendre dans la boutique des produits cosmétiques. Ses bénéfices lui serviront à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille, de renforcer son niveau d'épargne et de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
Marie Danièle M. is a 37-year old woman, married and the mother of four dependent children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of the association of Catholic Women of Tambacounda since that Banc Villageois branch had been launched on July 27, 2008. She had obtained four loans in the past, all duly repaid. She keeps a shop; with this new loan, she would like to purchase a refrigerator in order to sell cold drinks there. At the same time, she is going to also purchase cosmetic products to be retailed in her shop. Her income helps her improve the life conditions of her family, boost her savings and take care of her personal needs.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing a refrigerator and stocking up cosmetics

loans.name: Martin Ramón

texts.es:
Martin Ramón D. L. P. tiene una gran familia conformada por su esposa y 3 hijos D. 22 a 40 años. Él es propietario D. un negocio, en un interior D. un centro comercial muy popular, en L. zona central D.
