Faïssatou A. was born on April 29, 1968 in Sakété, in the Department of Ouémé. Faïssatou is married to Deen Amoussa and they have two children who are in school. Faïssatou has lived in the Dandji quarter of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, for the past eleven years, along with her husband and children. Together, the couple provides for the needs of the family. Faïssatou did not go to school. To meet her needs, Faïssatou sells assorted foodstuffs (maïze, manioc flour, pasta, rice, canned food, fresh tomatoes, etc.) in Abattoir, in the Sèmè-Podji commune. Faïssatou buys her stock in the interior of the country. This is the second loan that Faïssatou has requested from ALIDé; she wants to increase her working capital in order to finance an expansion of the business. Faïssatou repaid the first loan she received from ALIDé on time.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy maïze and manioc flour.

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 2  est issu de l’Association  de femmes mariées du village de Dah Manakina de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 36 ans, 4 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
Karya Traoré, la présidente du groupe compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants pour la culture. 
Karya s’approvisionne  au grand marché de San ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Dah, San  et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilise pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 2 group is an offshoot of the Association of Married Women of the village of Dah Manakin in the San prefecture. The San prefecture is located in the region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families. On average, they are 36 years old, have 4 children, and grow peanuts. In order to make their business profitable, the group members decided to use Soro Yiriwaso's loan program three years ago. Now that they have repaid the first two loans, they are seeking a third. Karya Traoré, the President of the group, plans to use her loan to buy a supply of peanut seed as well as assorted agricultural material and supplies. Karya buys her supplies in the main market of the city of San. After the rainy season, the harvest is warehoused for some time to increase its value. It is then sold in the main markets of Dah and San as well as in other surrounding markets, in retail (often at wholesale), and for cash to a clientele that is usually from the big cities. The group's members each expect to realize a profit of 35,000 FCFA from the sales of their agricultural produce, which will be used to reimburse interest on the loan and to pay for their families' living expenses.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seed and assorted agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Mrs. Theeda Em Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Theeda E. is 41 years old and is one member of a group seeking a loan in Prey Mien village in Takeo province. Mrs. Theeda E. has been selected the group leader by the the seventeen group members. Each group member will use a portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Theeda E. and her husband, Mr. Chhoeun Ben, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. In addition to being farmers, Mrs. Theeda E. is also a pig breeder and her husband is also a construction worker. These additional jobs help thE. to earn a small income to support their family's daily needs. In order to support her pig breeding business, Mrs. Theeda E. decided to ask for a loan to bU. piglets and pig food. This couple has five children; one is a salesperson and four are attending the local school. All the group members are shown in the photo, but some of thE. are blocked.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Julienne

texts.en:
Julienne is 45 years old. She is married and has seven children. One of her children has a business and the other six are in school. Two of her children graduated from high school and are entering college, two are in secondary school, and two are in primary school. 

Julienne is an industrious lady who sells sweet potatoes and local sorghum beer wholesale. She has been in this business since she was 18 years old. Also, when it’s time to harvest a particular crop, Julienne and her husband buy the produce locally and sell it in the city. 

She is requesting a loan in order to buy sacks of sorghum for her inventory, because she expects the sorghum season to end soon and the prices to rise.

loans.use: Buying sorghum to stock for the next season when it's scarce

loans.name: Marie Jeanne

texts.en:
Marie Jeanne is 34 years old. She is married and has four children between the ages of 8 and 15 years.  All of her children are in school and she is doing well with her family.  

Marie Jeanne sells used clothes, including men's shirts, and bedsheets. She has been in this business for 14 years.  She is requesting for a loan to buy more clothes.  Her dream is to make enough profit that she can buy a house of her own.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 42 years old. She is married and has seven children who range from 1 to 22 years old. Four of her children are in school, two have graduated, and the youngest child is not yet of school age. 

Beatrice and her husband have a hardware store in the market where they sell charcoal stoves, knives, and other metal and plastic equipment. She has been in this business for 24 years and her business is doing well.

Beatrice is requesting this loan to buy more equipment.  She says that she has a large clientele because of her good customer care.

loans.use: Buying more hardware such as knives,metal charcoal stoves, etc.

loans.name: Speciose

texts.en:
Speciose is 43 years old. She is married and has 5 children who range from 5-20 years of age. She is very hard-working and likes what she does for a living.  She has put all her children through school.

Speciose sells both local and commercial beer, as well as skewered meat. The local beer is made from amakashi, a type of banana, and sorghum, which helps ferment the banana juice. She has been in this business for 20 years and her business is doing well.  

She is requesting a loan to buy more beer and hopes to make enough profits one day to buy a house.

loans.use: Buying alcoholic drinks for her bar and animals for skewered meat.

loans.name: Benkadi 3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI 3  est issu de l’Association  de femmes mariées du village de Dah Manakina de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans,  5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
Hawa Dembélé, la présidente du groupe envisage utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, au grand marché de San ville. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Dah, San  et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 40.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
BENKADI 3 group is issued from the Association of married women of Dah Manakina, a village in San prefecture, Segou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and average 30 years of age and 5 children, and they grow peanuts. Eager to make their farming businesses profitable, the members of the group decided three years ago to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. After having repaid the previous loans without problems, they are now seeking their third farming loan. Hawa Dembélé, the group's president, intends to use her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, small materials, and fertilizers, at the grand market in the city of San. After the rainy season, her crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Dah, San, and at other markets in the surroundings. She sells retail, and often wholesale, for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities. After selling their farming products, the members of the group intend to turn a profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 75) each, to be used to repay the loan and pay the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, small materials and fertilizers

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee is married and has seven children. Six of her children are in school; the youngest has not yet started school.

Immaculee sells cow and goat hides.  She collects them in the neighborhood and sells them to people from the city.  Her clients treat the hides and either export them or sell them to people who make leather products, such as sandals, belts, etc. She has done this business for five years and she is proud of it. 

With this loan, she plans to buy more hides in order to make more profits. She has been selling 30 hides per day and hopes to increase her sales to 80 hides per day.If all goes well, with the profits, she hopes to expand her business even more by buying more hides.

loans.use: Buying more hides in order to make more profits

loans.name: Marie Rose

texts.en:
Marie Rose is 29 years old. She is married and three children who range from 2-7 years of age. Two of her children are in school, and the youngest child is not yet of school age. 

Marie Rose and her husband sell second-hand bicycles, sorghum, and a local beer called "urwagwa."  Both businesses are profitable, but the bicycles give her more income. 

With this loan, she hopes to buy more bicycles, and with the increased profits, she hopes to buy more sorghum and beans. She sells five bicycles per week, but she hopes to sell at least 20 bicycles per week in order to make more profits and support her children.

loans.use: Buying more bicycles and food to sell

loans.name: Jeanne D'arc

texts.en:
Jeanne D’Arc is married and has two children.  One of her children is 11 months old and the other is 3 years and five months old and is in school.  Her husband works with a micro-finance bank.  

She owns a store that carries scholastic materials for primary and secondary students.  She is requesting a loan to increase the selection of scholastic items she sells. She says that her business is well-known because of her good customer care. She has been in  this business for three years. She plans to save enough so that she can buy her own house one day.

loans.use: Buying more scholastic materials

loans.name: Poem's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Poem M. is 59 years old and the leader of a group loan. She was selected by its four members who are located in Chrey Tnoat village in Takeo province. The members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Poem M. and her husband, Mr. Touch Nouch, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. Besides farming, Mrs. Poem M. is also a pig breeder at home and is able to earn a small income to support her family. In order to support her pig breeding business, Mrs. Poem M. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets. She will use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizer to support her farming crop. This couple has three children; one is a goldsmith and the other two are students and help their parents with their businesses.

loans.use: To buy piglets and fertilizer

loans.name: Everyne

texts.en:
Everyne is 32 years old. She is married and three children who are all in school.  Her children range from ages 4-12 years. 

Everyne has a bar and a food store.  She has been in  this business for 8 years. Her husband is a driver. 

Evelyn hopes to use this loan to buy more alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks in order to make more profits. With the profits, she hopes to expand her business by buying more drinks and food.

loans.use: Buying more alcoholic drinks and food for her bar

loans.name: Gaudelive

texts.en:
Gaudelive is the mother of four children who range from 7-15 years of age. She is 34 years old and very hard working.

Gaudelive is a tailor and she also sells fabric. The fabrics are used to make clothes when the tailor measures the client and makes a particular clothing items such as a shirt, dress, etc.  She works with her husband and has operated this business for 10 years.  

With the loan, she hopes to buy more fabric.  She also hopes to save enough of the profits to buy her own house and run her business from there.

loans.use: Buying more fabric for making clothes, such as dresses.

loans.name: Marthe

texts.en: Marthe is married and has a one-year-old child.  She and her husband sell used clothes and shoes. They have been in this business for two years.  She currently sells in the market, but with the loan, she plans to rent a shop.  This will give her a permanent place to display and store her goods, and will relieve her from having to set up her stall in the market each time she sells and will give her more time to develop her business.

loans.use: To rent a shop for her used clothing business

loans.name: Peline

texts.en:
Peline is 29 years old. She is married and has three children who range from 2 weeks to seven years of age. The eldest is in school and the others are not yet of school age.

Peline sells shoes in the market. Her husband runs the same business, but in a different location.  She has been in this business for seven years. 

Peline wants a loan to buy more shoes to sell. With the profits from this loan, she hopes to increase her shoe inventory.

loans.use: Buying more shoes to sell

loans.name: Eleda

texts.en:
Eleda is 53 years old and has four children.  The youngest are in school and the eldest are married.  She has cattle and sells milk and a few foods, such as beans, that she gets from her garden.

Eleda works with her husband. She has been in this business for over 20 years. With the loan, she hopes to expand her milk business and buy more food products to sell. She plans to work hard and make enough profits to buy a house.

loans.use: Expand milk business and buy more food to sell

loans.name: Massan

texts.fr:
Agée de 41 ans, A. massan est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Pour contribuer aux charges familiales, elle fait le commerce de céréales.
Elle voyage régulièrement à l’intérieur du pays où elle achète maïs, arachide et haricots qu’elle revend ensuite au détail à son domicile. Elle exerce cette activité depuis plus de 5 ans aujourd’hui.
Le crédit actuellement sollicité est destiné à l’achat de céréales pour les besoins de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Massan A., age 41, is married and the mother of three children. To help with the family expenses, she sells cereals. She travels to the interior of the country on a regular basis, to buy corn, peanuts, and beans, that she then retails at her home. She's been running this business for more than five years today. The loan she's seeking now will be used to buy cereals for her clientele.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Benkadi 4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 4  est issu de l’Association  de femmes mariées du village de Dah Manakina de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, au moins 5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
Fanta Dembélé envisage utiliser son prêt  pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, exclusivement  au grand marché de San ville. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est  stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Dah, San et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Fanta Dembélé à l’instar des autres membres du groupe compte réaliser, après l’écoulement de sa production destinée à la vente, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 4 group comes from the Married Women's Association of the village of Dah Manakina in the prefecture of San, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members live in traditional families. They have an average age of 34 and on average at least 5 children each, and they grow peanuts. Wishing to make their agricultural enterprises more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After having reimbursed their preceding loans, they are on their third agricultural loan for this growing season. Fanta Dembélé intends to use her share of the loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds and various small implements and agricultural entrants, purchasing exclusively at the big open-air market of San city. During the off-season, she warehouses her harvest for a certain time so that it grows in value before selling it at the Dan and San markets and in surrounding marketplaces, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to a clientele generally coming from the big cities. After that part of her production that is destined to be sold is gone, Fanta Dembélé, like the other members of the group, expects to make a profit of 35,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for on-going family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of agricultural entrants, seed, etc.

loans.name: Benkadi 5 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi  5  est issu de l’Association  de femmes mariées du village de Dah Manakina de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, au moins 6 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
Fatoumata Konaté compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants, exclusivement  au grand marché de San ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Dah, San et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 5 group comes from the Married Women's Association of the village of Dah Manakina in the prefecture of San, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members live in traditional families. They have an average age of 37 and on average at least 6 children each, and they grow peanuts. Wishing to make their agricultural enterprises more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After having reimbursed their preceding loans correctly, they are on their third agricultural loan for the growing season. Fatoumata Konaté intends to use her share of the loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds and various small implements and agricultural entrants, purchasing exclusively at the big open-air market of San city. During the off-season, she warehouses her harvest for a certain time so that it grows in value before selling it at the Dan and San markets and in surrounding marketplaces, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to a clientele generally coming from the big cities. After their produce is sold, the members of the group each expect to make a profit of 25,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for on-going family expenses., like the other members of the group, expects to make a profit of 35,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for on-going family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of agricultural entrants, seed, etc.

loans.name: Yawa

texts.fr:
A. yawa est âgée de 20 ans et est célibataire. Elle est secrétaire de formation  et fournit différentes prestations de services dans le domaine informatique et bureautique.
Elle fait des traitements de textes, des photocopies et la ventes de divers articles de bureau.
Avec le crédit sollicité, elle envisage acheter une photocopieuse pour répondre aux besoins de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
A. Yawa, 20, is single. She has trained to be a secretary and she offers her customers various computer and secretarial services. She prepares and prints texts, makes photocopies, and sells various office supplies. With this loan she intends to buy a photocopier so as to meet the demand of her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a photocopier

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is married with four children and all her children go to school. She takes care of additional family members. She owns a chicken stall in Kisaasi market in Nakawa Division Kampala District and sells to all categories of people on retail. She wants to use this loan to buy more chickens for resale. She uses public transport to and from buying chickens and buys these chickens from poultry farmers in Namugongo Kyanja, Komamboga and Ntinda. She goes shopping twice a week. Caroline sells broilers and layers locally. She has been in this business for ten years. Her business challenges include transportation and thieves. She is aspiring to see her business grow big and to start rearing chickens herself. Caroline decided to join MCDT because they were giving out timely loans. She resides in and owns a two roomed house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for resale

loans.name: Mrs. Chan Noeun Sam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan Noeun S. is 36 years old and the village bank president. She was selected by its fourteen members who are located in Trapeang Chhuk village in Takeo province. With the loan, the members hope to increase their income to improve their families' standard of livI.. 

Mrs. Chan Noeun S. is a pig breeder and her husband, Mr. Thy Eat, is a construction worker. With both of these positions, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to support her pig breedI. business, Mrs. Chan Noeun S. decided to ask for a loan to buy two more piglets for breedI.. This couple has three children who are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more two piglets for breeding

loans.name: Ali

texts.fr:
M. ali est âgé de 27 ans, est célibataire avec 2 enfants. Il est agent commercial au sein d’une institution de la place. Pour les besoins de ses activités, il a besoin d’un moyen de locomotion. C’est pour cette raison qu’il sollicite ce crédit de WAGES. 
Ce crédit sera donc destiné à l’achat d’une moto. 
Il espère avec l’évolution probable de son activité due à ce crédit, augmenter et conforter son autonomie financière.
texts.en:
M. Ali, 27, is single with two children. He is a commercial employee in a local company. In order to do his job, he needs a means of transportation. For that reason, he is requesting this loan from WAGES. The loan is intended to buy a motorcycle. As he becomes able to do a better job, he hopes he will increase his financial independence and improve his family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a motorcycle

loans.name: Mrs. Ngaet Bich Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Ngaet B. is 38 years old and the village bank president. She was selected by its 16 members located in Trapeang Chhuk village in Takeo province. Each member of this village loan will use the loan to support a different purpose. Mrs. Ngaet B. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice, and her husband, Mr. Pen Soeung, is a construction worker who receives a small salary to support his family. In order to increase income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Ngaet B. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. This couple has four children. One of the children is a seamstress in a garment factory and the others are students who also help their mother with the farming. All the members are shown in the picture but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Benkadi 6 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi  6 est issu de l’Association  de femmes mariées du village de Dah Manakina du cercle San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, 5 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
Sitan D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants,  au grand marché de San ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Dah, San  et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 6 group comes from the Married Women's Association of the village of Dah Manakina in the prefecture of San, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members live in traditional families. They have an average age of 34, at least 5 children each, and they grow peanuts. Wishing to make their agricultural enterprises more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After having reimbursed their preceding loans correctly, they are on their third agricultural loan for the growing season. Sitan D. intends to use her share of the loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds and various small implements and agricultural entrants, at the big open-air market of San city. During the off-season, her harvest will be warehoused for a certain time so that it grows in value before selling it at the Dan and San markets and in surrounding marketplaces, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to a clientele generally coming from the big cities. After their produce is sold, the members of the group each expect to make a profit of 35,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for on-going family expenses., like the other members of the group, expects to make a profit of 35,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for on-going family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of entrants, seed, etc.

loans.name: Afi Ame

texts.fr:
Agée de 34 ans, A. afi est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Pour contribuer aux charges du ménage, elle tient une épicerie. Dans sa boutique dénommée « Epicerie Centrale », elle  vend des épices, cubes en gros et en détail.
Elle a débuté cette activité en 2005 et la maitrise assez bien.
Le présent crédit a pour objet l’achat d’épice et d’ails pour les besoins de son commerce.
texts.en:
A. Afi, age 34, is married and the mother of two children. To help with the family's expenses, she runs a grocery store. In her shop, called "Epicerie Centrale", she sells spices, and bouillon cubes, wholesale and retail. She started this business in 2005, and now masters it quite well. The loan she's seeking will be used to buy spices and garlic for her store.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spices and garlic

loans.name: Cate

texts.en: Cate is married with four children; two of her children go to school and the other ones are still young. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. Cate owns a restaurant in Kyebando market, selling all types of food. She wants to use this loan to buy more foodstuffs like bananas, rice, cassava and cooking utensils. She has been in this business for six years and her customers are her fellow market vendors. She works six days a week. Her business challenges include defaulters and ever-increasing prices of foodstuffs. She is aspiring to educate her children up to university level. She decided to work with MCDT because it was giving out loans to poor women who are in groups of five. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like bananas, cassava and cooking utensils

loans.name: Kossiwa Dodo

texts.fr:
D. kossiwa a 40 ans  et reste encore très dynamique. Elle est mariée et a un enfant. Elle tient une boutique de vente de produits d’alimentation générale. Elle y vend différents produits tels que savon de Marseille, sacs de riz, boites de conserves, de lait.
Avec le prêt demandé, elle envisage acheter des cartons de savons, de sardines et de beurre pour soutenir les besoins de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Kossiwa D. is 40 years old and remains very energetic She's married and has one child. She runs a shop were she sells food staples and other products, such as Marseille soaps, sacks of rice, canned food, and milk. She intends to use the loan she's seeking to buy boxes of soaps, sardines, and butter, to meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boxes of soaps, sardines, and butter

loans.name: Benkadi  1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 1 est d’une Association  de femmes mariées du village de Djigonso de la sous préfecture de Yangasso, préfecture  de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 43 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent essentiellement  du riz. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe   Benkadi 1 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé leur prêt solidaire, elles décident de venir aux prêts de campagne  étant données que leur activité principale en hivernage est la culture du riz, d’où leur premier de prêt de campagne.
Koniba T. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences de riz, des petits équipements, le paiement des ouvriers  et des intrants pour mieux rentabiliser les récoltes. Les achats se font exclusivement  au grand marché de Bla ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées (une partie consommée) pendant un certains  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché Yangasso, Bla et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Benkadi 1 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 1 group is an association of married women from the Djigonso village in the sub prefecture of Yangasso (prefecture of San), in Segou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They live in traditional families, and on average, they are 43-years old and have at least 6 children. They mainly grow rice. In order to make their farms profitable, the members of Benkadi 1 decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. Having fully repaid their group loan, they switched to farming loans since their primary activity during the rainy season is growing rice. They are seeking their first farming loan. Koniba T. plans to use the loan to buy a sufficient quantity of rice seeds and small farming tools, and pay for labor and planting supplies to help increase harvest profitability. Purchases are made exclusively at the main market of the town of Bla. After the rainy season, the harvest is stored (some is used) for a certain amount of time in order to gain value prior to being sold at the markets of Yangasso, Bla, and other surrounding markets, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities. Once the products are sold, the group members of Benkadi 1 hope to make a profit of 30,000FCFA each, which would be used to repay the loan interest and cover the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase planting supplies, seeds, small farming tools, and to pay for labor

loans.name: Judyciane Doride

texts.fr:
Jeune femme commercante agee de 35 ans,celibataire avec 2 enfants dont l'age varie entre  17 et 15 ans,Quand elle arrete ses etudes en 2000, elle etait deja fille mere, par manque de soutien elle se lance dans l'alimentation pour prendre soin des siens. 

Avec le pret qu'elle va recevoir , elle va renforcer son activite en achetant des cartons de lait,des cartons de beurre , de la margarine, des boites de conserves tel que la sardine, corn boeuf, pilchard ...a tout cela elle ajoute des pots de yaourts, de la boisson gazeuse, des sacs de sucre, de la farine  et tout ce dont les clients recherchent le plus  souvent.
Elle use de beaucoup de strategie pour faire croitre son activite, elle a des prix abordables,et presentent aux clients les produits de bonne qualite.
A l'avenir elle pense a beaucoup epargner pour soutenir les etudes des ses enfants qui sont deja au lycee, elle se bat ,elle ne veut pas que ses enfants arretent leurs etudes comme elle par manque de soutien, c'est son plus grand soucis, tres serviable , tout le monde la connait dans le quartier.
texts.en:
Judyciane Doride M., age 35, is a young merchant. She's unmarried and has two children, aged 15 and 17. When she abandoned her studies in 2000, she was already a single mother. Lacking support, she started a food business to provide for her family. With this loan, she's going to bolster her business by buying boxes of milk and butter, margarine, canned food such as sardines, corned beef, pilchards… To this, she adds yoghurts, soft drinks, sacks of sugar, flour, and everything her customers are looking for. To bolster her business, one of her many strategies is to offer affordable prices to her customers, as well as good quality products. In the future, she's think of saving a lot of money to support her children's studies. They are already in high school, and she's fighting because she doesn't want them to abandon their studies due to lack of support, as she did. This is her main concern. She's very helpful and everyone knows her in the neighborhood.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy dairy products, butter, breads, canned food, boxes of soaps, etc

loans.name: Benkadi  2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 2 est d’une Association  de femmes mariées du village de Djigonso dans la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies et ont en moyenne 43 ans et au moins 8 enfants.
Elles  font essentiellement la culture du riz. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe   Benkadi 2 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé tous les  prêts solidaires,  elles ont décidé de virer au prêt de campagne puisse que leur activité principale  en hivernage est la culture du riz.
Rachelle Dembélé compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de riz, des petits équipements  et des intrants agricoles. 
Elle s’approvisionne exclusivement  au grand marché de Yangasso ville. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est stockée pendant un certains  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Rachelle compte réaliser tout comme les autres membres du groupe, après écoulement de son produit agricole, un bénéfice de 35000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 2 Group is an association of married women from the village of Djigonso, San prefecture, in Ségou Region (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in extended traditional families. Their average age is 43; each has at least eight children. They are rice growers. Hoping to improve the efficiency of their farming operations, Benkadi 2 decided to take part in Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. They have repaid their membership loans, decided to apply for a business loan. In the winter season their main activity is growing rice. Rachelle Dembélé plans on using her loan to buy rice seed, small tools and fertilizer. She will get them at the big market in Yangasso town. Once winter is over, she will keep what she has harvested long enough for the price to rise before selling it at the big market in Kimparana and in other local markets, mostly by selling it directly to customers but also wholesaling it. Her customers mostly come from large towns. After she has sold her produce, Rachelle (like other group members) hopes to realize a profit of 35,000 FCFA, to be used to service her loan and to pay for ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice seed, fertilizer and small farming tools

loans.name: Mawuko Adakou

texts.fr:
Agée de 57 ans, G. adakou mawuko demeure très active. Elle tient une boutique de vente de produits d’alimentation générale. Elle y vend différents produits tels que savon de marseille, sacs de riz, boites de conserves, de lait.
Avec le prêt demandé, elle envisage acheter des cartons de savons, de sardines et de riz pour soutenir les besoins de sa clientèle.
Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
G. Adakou Mawuko is an active 57 year-old. She owns a shop that sells general foods, such as Marseille soap, bags of rice, jars of jam, and milk. She aims to use the loan in order to purchase boxes of soap, sardines, and rice in order to meet her customers' demand. She is married with one child.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of general foods

loans.name: Akpédzé

texts.fr:
Cette jeune femme de 28 ans est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Pour contribuer aux charges du ménage, elle tient une boutique de vente de produits d’alimentation générale.
Elle y vend différents produits tels que des pates alimentaires, des  sacs de riz, boites de conserves, de lait.
Avec le prêt demandé, elle envisage acheter des cartons de savons, de sardines et sucre pour soutenir les besoins de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
This young lady is 28 years old and married with one child. She sells general foods so that she can contribute to her family's needs. She sells pasta, bags of rice, jars of jam, and milk. She aims to use the requested loan to purchase boxes of soap, sardines and sugar so that she may meet her customers' demands.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of general foods

loans.name: Benkadi  3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI 3 est d’une Association  de femmes mariées du village de Djigonso de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 48 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait essentiellement la  culture  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé  leur  prêt solidaire,  elles ont décidé de virer au prêt de campagne d'où leur premier prêt de campagne.
Djeneba Soukoulé compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de riz, des petits équipements et des intrants pour se rassurer d’une bonne récolte. 
Les achats se font  exclusivement  au grand marché de Bla ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Bla ,Yangasso et dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is a credit association made up of married women from the Djigonso village in the San municipality, Segou region (the fourth largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional households and are around 48 years old with 4 children. This group of women primarily cultivate peanuts for a living. In order to generate greater profits from their agricultural activities, the members of the group have decided to seek a loan from Soro Yiriwaso. They have already repaid their first loan, and so have decided to seek a second loan, which will be the first loan of their current campaign. Djeneba Soukoulé aims to use the loan to purchase an adequate quantity of rice grain, small tools and other inputs in order to secure a good harvest. The purchases are exclusively from the large Bla town market. After wintering the plants, the harvest is stocked for a while so that they might rise in value before being sold at Bla, Yangasso and in the other markets. They are sold for cash individually or in bulk to a customer base mainly in large towns. The members of the group aim to generate a profit of 25,000 FCFA which will be utilised to repay the loan and to meet their families' costs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inputs, grain and small tools

loans.name: Essi Edzodzinam

texts.fr:
Née en 1976, cette dame est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Pour contribuer aux charges du ménage, elle achète et revend des boissons locales spécialement de l’alcool communément appelé « SODABI ».
Elle s’approvisionne à Kpalimé et revend  sa boisson dans une baraque sise à son domicile.
Avec le crédit sollicité, elle compte acheter 20 bidons de boisson pour relancer son commerce.
texts.en:
Born in 1976, this lady is married with one child. In order to contribute to household costs, she buys and sells local drinks, especially an alcoholic beverage called 'Sodabi'. She sources her wares in Kpalimé and sells it from a shed located at her home. She aims to use the loan to purchase 20 flasks of the beverage in order to boost her business.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of flasks of drink

loans.name: Benkadi 4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 4  est composé  de femmes mariées du village de Djigonso de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 38 ans et au moins 4 enfants et  cultivent  du riz. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé  leur premier prêt, solidaire, elles se sont tournées avec le prêt de campagne, les activités de l’hivernage obligent.
Minata Dembélé compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence, des petits équipements  et des intrants pour la culture.
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Bla et de Yangasso ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Yangasso, Bla et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 42500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 4 group is made up of married women from the Djigonso village in the San municipality, the Segou region (the fourth largest administrative region of Mali). They live in traditional households, are around 38 years-old and have 4 children; they grow rice for a living. In order to generate higher profits from their operations, they have decided to seek a loan from Soro Yiriwaso. Having successfully repaid their first loan, they are seeking another in order to assist with the cultivation of their crops. Minata Dembélé aims to use the loan in order to purchase an adequate quantity of grain, small tools and inputs for growing crops. They source their goods from the large market at Bla and from the Yangasso town market. After wintering the crops, the harvest is stored for a while in order to gather value before being sold at the large Yangasso, Bla and other markets. Sales are in cash for individual or bulk items, and the customer base generally comes from large towns. The group members aim to generate an average profit of 42,500 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan interest and to meet the family's everyday costs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inputs, grain and small tools

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Agée de 44 ans, D. abra est mariée avec 3 enfants. Elle est commerçante de tissus.
Il s’agit des tissus coupons qu’elle achète à Lomé et qu’elle revend comme ambulante de quartiers en quartiers. Elle exerce cette activité depuis plus de 20 ans.
Le crédit actuellement sollicité servira à l’achat de 25 pièces de tissu coupon et 30 pièces de draps.
Comptant sur l’accroissement de son activité, elle espère mieux répondre aux besoins de scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Abra D. is 44, and is married with three children. She buys cloth in Lomé and sells it as piece goods from door to door in different neighborhoods. She has been doing this for more than 20 years. The loan she is now asking for will be used to buy 25 pieces of cloth and 30 sheets. She hopes to increase her business so as to better take care of her children's educational needs.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cloth and sheets

loans.name: Benkadi  5 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 5  est composé de femmes mariées du village de Djigonso  de la préfecture de San,  région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 36 ans, au moins 6 enfants et cultivent  du riz. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts solidaires, elles  sont venues au  prêt de campagne. C’est leur  premier prêt  de campagne.
Alima C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de riz, des petits équipements et des intrants pour la culture. 
Alima s’approvisionne  au grand marché de Bla. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte (une partie consommée) est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Bla et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Alima C. tout comme les autres membres du groupe Benkadi 5 compte réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 45.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi Group is made up of married women from the village of Djigonso, San prefecture, in Ségou Region (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. Their average age is 36; each has at least six children and is a rice farmer. Hoping to improve the efficiency of their farming operations, the group's members decided to take part in Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. They have repaid their membership loans, and are now ready for their first business loan. Alima C. plans on using her loan to buy rice seed, small tools and fertilizer. She will get them at the big market in Bla. Once winter is over, she will use some of what she harvests and keep the rest long enough for the price to rise before selling it at Bla and in other local markets, mostly by selling it directly to customers but also wholesaling it. Her customers mostly come from large towns. After she has sold her produce, Alima C. (like other group members) hopes to realize a profit of 45,000 FCFA, to be used to service her loan and to pay for ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice seed, fertilizer and small farming tools

loans.name: Benkadi 6 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 6  est composé de six femmes mariées du village de Djigonso de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies, ont en moyenne 38 ans, au moins 4 enfants et cultivent essentiellement de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso.  Après avoir correctement remboursé  leur premier   prêt qui était  un crédit solidaire, ce groupe est à son deuxième prêt  qui est cette fois ci un crédit de campagne. 
Kadia C. qui est la présidente du groupe compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de riz, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture. 
Kadia s’approvisionne exclusivement au grand marché de Bla ville. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte, une partie consommée  et l’autre partie  est  stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Kadia C. tout comme les cinq autres membres du groupe compte réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30.000  FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 6 group is composed of six married women from the Djigonso village in the San prefecture, Ségou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They live in traditional extended families, are on the average 38 years old, have at least four children and mainly cultivate peanuts. In order to make their farm work profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiwaso. Having duly repaid their first loan, which was a solidarity loan, they are now on their second loan, this time a farming loan. Kadia C., who is the group leader, plans to use her part of the loan to purchase a sufficient quantity of rice seeds, small tools and fertilizers. Kadia stocks up exclusively at the big market of the town of Bla. After the winter season, part of her harvest is consumed and the other is stocked for a while until it goes up in price and she can then sell it at the big market of Kimparana and at other regional markets, retail (often wholesale too), for cash to customers mainly coming from large towns.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizers and small farming tools

loans.name: Armel Chrysler

texts.fr:
Jeune homme de 32 ans,marié père d'une fille de 2ans, par manque de moyen financier il arrette ses etudes au secondaire et il commence  la vente des produits pharmaceutiques en 2002 avec un capital de 4000f.,il s'approvisionne dans les grands depots pharmaceutiques de la place, il vend en moyenne 10.000 frs par jour.

Avec le pret qu'il compte recevoir  il va acheter des cartons de glucose; des solutions salees ,des produits de malaria, des produits diarrheiques, alcool, bétadine,comprimés paracétamols,quinines à et autres produits de premieres nécessitées.

Avec les bénéfices que ses ventes vont générées, il va améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille,
Continuer dans cette activité est son soucis majeur, il veut a la longue ouvrir une grande pharmacie ,dans son milieu  social,il est connu  parmi les jeunes qui se débrouillent.
texts.en:
He is 32, married with a two-year-old daughter. He couldn't afford to finish high school, and in 2002 began selling pharmaceuticals with an investment of F4000. He buys his stock from large downtown pharmacies, and his daily turnover averages F10,000. With the loan he hopes to receive, he will buy boxes of glucose, saline solution, anti-malarial and anti-diarrhea medications, alcohol, betadine, paracetamol pills, quinine and other basics. With the profits that his sales should generate, he will improve his family's living conditions. In the short term he will keep up his present activity, but in the long term he wants to open a large pharmacy. In his social circle he is well known among young people trying to get on in lifee.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pharmaceuticals:  glucose, saline, malaria products, anti-diarrhea medication.

loans.name: Benkadi 7 Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 7  est un regroupement de cinq  femmes mariées du village de Djigonso de la préfecture de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans, ont au moins 7 enfants et cultivent  du riz. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts solidaires, elles sont venues au prêt de campagne.
Sanata T. compte utiliser son prêt  pour acheter, de la semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants pour la culture. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Bla ville. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Bla et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Benkadi 7 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de  28.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 7 group is made up of five married women from the village of Djigonso, in the prefecture of San, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. They have an average age of 38 and at least 7 children each, and they grow rice. Wishing to make their agricultural enterprises more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having reimbursed their solidarity loans correctly, they are requesting an agricultural loan for the growing season. Sanata T. intends to use her share of the loan to buy seeds, various small implements and agricultural entrants, purchasing at the big market of Bla town. After the off-season, she stockpiles her harvest for a certain time so that it grows in value before selling it at the big Bla market and in surrounding marketplaces, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to a clientele generally coming from the big cities. After their agricultural produce is sold, the members of the Benkadi 7 group each expect to make a profit of 28,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of entrants, seed, and various agricultural necessities

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina P. is currently in the business of selling fish, tomatoes, onions and cooking oil. She is requesting a loan to stock Irish potatoes to sell. 

Regina is 46 years old and married to a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr:
A. Essi est née en 1983 et est célibataire. Elle est employée de bureau.
Dans le but de diversifier ses revenus, elle achète et revend des cartes de recharge. Elle a commencé à explorer ce secteur d’activité depuis 2007 et maitrise assez bien le secteur. L’activité se déroule dans une cabine téléphonique située au centre ville. 
Avec le prêt demandé, elle envisage acheter des cartes de recharge pour relancer son commerce.
Elle espère avec l’évolution probable de son activité due à ce crédit, augmenter et conforter son autonomie financière.
texts.en:
A. Essi was born in 1983 and she is single. She is employed in an office. In order to diversify her income, she buys and re-sells rechargeable telephone cards. She got her start in this sector in 2007 and is quite familiar with it. Her business is located in a telephone booth situated in the center of town. With the requested loan, she intends to buy rechargeable cards to get her business going again. She hopes that because of the influence of this loan on her business, she will be able to be more financially independent.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of rechargeable phone cards

loans.name: Flavia

texts.en:
Flavia is married with three children; two of her children go to school and the third one is 3 months old. She also takes care of two orphans. She owns a stall in Kawempe Market, selling bananas. She has been in this business for nine years.  

She wants to buy more bunches of bananas. She buys these bunches of bananas from villages of the Masaka district in central Uganda. She works seven days a week and her customers are both women and men. Her business challenges include transportation of the bunches of bananas from Masaka to Kawempe and the rainy season. She uses public transport to and from the villages to get her stock. She aspires to buy land and to educate her children up to the university level. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged.  

Flavia resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, food and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce K. is currently in the business of selling dried fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and Irish potatoes to sell. Joyce is 31 years old and married to a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock tomatoes and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Komi

texts.fr:
Agé de 35 ans,M. Komi est marié et père de 2 enfants. Comme activité génératrice de revenus, il achète et revend des chaussures.
Il vend une gamme variée de chaussures pour femmes, hommes et enfants qu’il expose sur un étalage à coté de la station service Total d’Adidogomé. Elle exerce cette  activité depuis 2004.
Le crédit sollicité est destiné à l’achat de nouveaux stocks de chaussures pour satisfaire la demande de la clientèle.
texts.en:
M. Komi, 35, is married and the father of two children. To earn a living he sells shoes. He sells a wide range of shoes for women, men and children which he displays beside the Total Service Station in Adidogomé. He has been in this business since 2004. The loan he is requesting is intended to purchase new stocks of shoes to satisfy the demand of his clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes for resale

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr:
âgée de 36 ans,A. akossiwa est mariée avec un enfant. Elle est revendeuse de céréales.
Elle achète du maïs et divers céréales à l’intérieur du pays et revend au marché d’Adidogomé dans le rayon des revendeuses de maïs.
Le présent crédit sera destiné à l’achat de nouveaux stocks de maïs pour assurer la saison prochaine.
Elle espère grâce à ce nouveau crédit accroitre sa marge bénéficiaire.
texts.en:
36 year old Akossiwa A. is married with one child. She sells cereals. She buys maize and other cereals in the interior of the country and resells them in the Adidogome market in the area for resellers of maize. This loan will be used to buy new stocks of maize to assure supply for the coming season. She hopes that thanks to this loan she will improve her profit margin.

Translated from French by Mark Latour, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of maize

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly is married with five children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Milly changed her business enterprise from selling local brew to selling bananas. She has been in this banana business for a few months. She owns a banana stall in Kawempe market and sells to all categories of people both at retail and wholesale.  She is now proud of the business.  

She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas and doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work.  She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters.  She aspires to seeing her business grow big and going directly to farmers.  She joined MCDT because she wanted capital to do business.  She resides in and rents a two-roomed house; the family has no access to electricity and piped water.   Her monthly expenses includes food, rent, and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Ferme

texts.en:
Ferme D. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize flour, beans, and sugar in a big store and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and beans to sell.  Ferme is 34 years old and married; her husband is a businessman. She has 3 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and beans to sell

loans.name: Adjowavi Josephine

texts.fr:
A 43 ans, adjossey adjowavi reste encore très dynamique. Elle achète et revend des chaussures.
Elle vend une gamme variée de chaussures pour femmes, hommes et enfants qu’elle expose sur un étalage à son domicile. Elle exerce cette  activité depuis 3 ans et maitrise assez bien le secteur.
Le crédit sollicité est destiné à l’achat de nouveaux stocks de chaussures pour satisfaire la demande de la clientèle.
Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
At 43 years, Adjowavi A. remains very dynamic. She is married and mother of a child. She buys and resells shoes. She sells a varied range of shoes for women, men and children which she displays at her residence. She has carried on this activity for 3 years and controls rather well this sector of the market. The requested credit is intended for the purchase of new stocks of shoes to satisfy the request of customers.

Translated from French by Mark Latour, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of shoes

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida S.  is currently in the business of selling first class dresses, trousers, and bedsheets and is requesting a loan to import more bedsheets from Khartoum to sell in Juba.  Aida is 31 years old and is married; her husband is a head teacher. She has two children who both go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a car for hire.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Import more bedsheets from Khartoum to sell in Juba

loans.name: Kodjo John

texts.fr:
A. kodzo edem est âgé de 37 ans, il est marié et père de 3 enfants. Pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille, il est revendeur de céréales.
il achète du maïs et divers céréales dans l’extrême nord du pays (Dapaong) et revend au marché d’Adidogomé dans le rayon des revendeurs de maïs.
Le présent crédit sera destiné à l’achat de nouveaux stocks de maïs pour satisfaire la demande de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Kodzo Edem A. is 37 years old, married and the father of 3 children. To provide for the needs of his family, he is a cereal retailer. He buys corn and various cereals in the extreme north of the country (Dapaong) and resells at the market of Adidogomé in the area for corn retailers. This loan is intended for the purchase of new cereal stocks to satisfy the request of customers.

Translated from French by Mark Latour, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals

loans.name: Kossi Sényo

texts.fr:
Cet homme de 49 ans est très dynamique. Il est agent de sécurité au sein d’une société de gardiennage de la place. Pour optimiser ses revenus, il est conducteur de taxi moto.
Afin de se procurer une nouvelle moto pour sa propre exploitation, il sollicite ce crédit de WAGES.
Il est marié et père de 4 enfants et espère qu’avec cette nouvelle moto, il pourra leur offrir une meilleure éducation.
texts.en:
This 49 year old man is very dynamic. He is security agent with a company guarding the square. To optimize his income, he also drives a taxi motor bike. In order to get a new motor bike for his own exploitation, he requests this loan from WAGES. He is married and father of 4 children and hopes that with this new motor bike, he will be able to offer a better education to them.

Translated from French by Mark Latour, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a motorbike

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a single mother of three children who all go to school.  She doesn’t take care of any additional family. She goes door to door selling second-hand clothes.   She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. Margaret buys bales of second-hand clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and uses public transport to and from shopping. She has been in this business for five years.  

Besides this clothing business she also owns a poultry farm at her home.  Her customers are the local people, and she works six days a week. Her business challenge is the rainy season which hinders her movements.  She aspires to getting a permanent business premise.  She joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital to boost her business. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house, which has neither electricity nor piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji W.  is currently in the business of selling fried fish at the street in the evening and is requesting a loan to stock more fish and some bread to sell.  Keji is 35 years old and married to a policeman. She has three children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more fish and some bread to sell

loans.name: Armila

texts.en:
Armila M. is currently in the business of selling furniture and sheets of iron at a shop. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of cement to sell.  

Armila is 39 years old and is married to an under secretary. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida J. is currently in the business of selling various items in a shop, such as earrings, necklaces, headdresses, etc. She is requesting a loan to stock more earrings and necklaces to sell.  

Farida is 49 years old and married to a labor office inspector. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more earrings and necklaces to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.fr:
jeune commercante de 39 ans, celibataire avec 1 enfant a sa charge, s'est lancee dans la vente des tissus a la fin de ses etudes au lycee, n'ayant pas de moyens pour payer ses etudes universitaires et ses parents etant morts, avec une somme de 30000frs  en 1999, elle achete quelques rouleaux de popeline et trouve un etalage au marche de moungali specialise dans la vente des tissus de qualite.
Elle vend en moyenne 20000f a 35000frs par jour et s'approvisionne dans les grands depots de la place,les commercants de Cotonou, de la Chine et de Kinshasa.
Avec l'octroi du pret elle compte acheter des tissus de qualite comme la soie,satin, velours,super 100, ergonza,popeline et tous les tissus a la mode.
Elle use de beaucoup de strategies pour faire croitre son activite,comme preter des tissus aux femmes  en bon dans des administrations,et jouer avec les prix et trouver des tissus a la mode a tout saison.

Tres connue dans son milieu,elle est tres ouverte et souriante avec ses clientes;dans peu de temps elle pense a ouvrir un grand magassin des tissus.
texts.en:
39 years young business person. Single with 1 child in her care. She embarked on the sale of fabrics at the end high school. Not having means to pay for university, her parents having died. With a sum of 30000 Francs in 1999, she bought some poplin rolls and got a display space in the market of Moungali specializing in the sale of fabrics of quality. She sells on average 20000frs to 35000frs per day and gets her supply in the large warehouses of the place. The traders of Cotonou, China and Kinshasa. With the loan she intends to buy fabrics of quality like silk, satin, velvet, super 100, ergonza, poplin and all the high fashion fabrics. She uses many strategies to grow her business, like lending fabrics to women in good standing, and is flexible with prices and tries to find fabrics in fashion at any season. Well known in her milieu, she is very open and smiling with her customers; soon she thinks to open a fabric department store.

Translated from French by Mark Latour, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy rolls of quality fabrics like silk, satin, velvet, super 100, ergonza, poplin

loans.name: Rehemah

texts.en:
Residing in a rented one-roomed house with no access to electricity or piped water, Rehemah, who is a married mother of two children, both attending school, also takes care of her mother.

Rehemah owns a stall in Kawempe selling chicken, a business she has operated for ten years, and works seven days a week. Using public transport, she buys chicken from poultry farmers in Kawempe Maganjo and Kazo areas in Kawempe Division. Her business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She wants to use this loan to buy more chicken, and she aspires to invest in a second-hand clothing business.

Rehemah joined MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting additional capital. Her greatest monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more chicken for resale

loans.name: Lakwa

texts.en:
Lakwa I., currently in the business of selling beer and local brew at home, is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials. Forty-five-years-old and married to a civil engineer, Lakwa has three children, all of whom attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to establish a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married woman from Lebanon with four school-aged children. After 10 years of experience selling accessories and perfumes, in 2008 she decided to open her own shop in her town to help her husband meet the heavy expenses of their household. During these past two years, she has met this goal.

Today, she is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her purchases of new perfumes and women's accessories to better market her products and increase the liquidity of her business.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her business
